Increased glutathione S-transferase Pi (GSTP1) activity has been recorded in human breast cancer compared to non-cancerous breast tissue. The aim of the present study was to evaluate the role of GSTP1 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) genotypes in the response of MCF-7 breast cancer cell line to ginger and its major constituents. In this study GSTP1 polymorphisms and mRNA expression were determined using polymerase chain reaction allele-specific restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) technique and real-time PCR. The effect of ginger and three of its major bioactive constituents, [6]-shogaol, [10]-shogaol and Zingiberine on the expression of GSTP1 was investigated. The results illustrated that GSTP1 polymorphisms did not play a significant role in breast cancer metastasis. In agreement with previously published data, the data obtained herein showed that the mRNA expression level of GSTP1 was induced by ginger and its major constituents. Our results showed that GSTP1 polymorphisms had no significant impact on breast cancer metastasis. However, the ability of ginger and its major constituents to alter GSTP1 gene expression may shed light on the molecular mechanisms behind the antimetastatic potential of ginger.

Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) is a bleeding disorder characterized by low platelet count due to anti-platelet antibodies, low platelet production, and increased platelet destruction. The clinical severity ranges from mild bruising to life-threatening bleeding. Different approaches, including supportive treatment, corticosteroids, intravenous immunoglobulin, thrombopoietin mimetics, splenectomy, and novel biological therapies have been described. Supportive measures in the form of replacement of platelets and iron supplementation are the cornerstone of the management of ITP. Corticosteroids are used in cases that do not respond to supportive therapy. The next available drug is thrombopoietin mimetics which work by binding to its receptor and result in the proliferation of megakaryocytes. These drugs are used when the patient has a low platelet count with symptoms of bleeding. Splenectomy is the fourth drug used following all the others. However, it may result in complications, such as portal hypertension and sepsis. New biological therapies, such as rituximab -an anti B cells monoclonal drug, and Fostamatinib -a Syk inhibitor, have been used successfully for ITP management.

# Introduction and background
Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP), formerly known as idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura was first described by MacCallum in 1884 as the bleeding disorder that results in the low platelet count. It is an autoimmune bleeding disorder resulting from impaired production and destruction of platelets, which is ultimately treated with platelet transfusions or intravenous immune globulin (IVIG). The etiology of the condition is unclear and includes multiple factors along with platelet destruction, such as impaired platelet production due to bone marrow suppression, accelerated megakaryocyte breakdown, and platelet sequestration. A1 A2 1 2 Tumor metabolism is remodeled by an oncolytic virus to activate caspase-dependent and caspase-independent apoptotic death pathways.
Genetically modified viruses can promote apoptotic cell death in cancer cells. Here, we analyzed the molecular mechanisms triggering the death of tumor cells infected with an attenuated vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV). Using both wild-type VSV and VSV derivatives engineered for the expression of the green fluorescence protein (GFP), we demonstrated that the oncolytic effect of VSV did not correlate directly with the level of viral protein production but with the intrinsic capacity of the virus to promote cell death. Furthermore, in cells infected with modified VSV harboring GFP, we confirmed that at least a population of cancer cells undergoes caspase-dependent apoptosis. Of interest, in cells exposed to VSV lacking the NS1 gene we noticed a GFP-negative subset undergoing death with the typical appearance of necrosis. The VSV-induced death pathways depended on the cell type infected with the virus, which in turn correlated with the amount of phospho-eIF2α induced. Apoptotic cell death induction by VSV required the production of viral proteins downstream of eIF2α-P. These findings are the first to demonstrate that the mechanism of activation of apoptosis by oncolytic viruses is not conserved within the same oncolytic virus lineage. Abstract We performed a meta-analysis to comprehensively evaluate the relationships between cigarette smoking and various metabolic abnormalities. We collected prospective cohort studies or case–control studies that reported the relationship between cigarette smoking and cardiovascular metabolic abnormalities in nondiabetic individual populations. The databases used to conduct electronic searches from the inception to October 2017 included the following: PubMed, Embase, the Cochrane Library and five Chinese databases. Data extraction was performed on the following parameters: first author, publication year, characteristics of individuals, smoking status and outcome. We finally included eighteen publications in our meta-analysis. The pooled results indicated that heavy smokers had a higher risk of hypertension, insulin resistance, dyslipidaemia, and overweight and obesity status than non-smokers and light smokers. Our results indicate that cigarette smoking can promote the incidence of cardiovascular metabolic syndrome, which has a significant effect on health in addition to the well-known association with cancer. The healthy lifestyle concept of quitting smoking may help individuals to avoid metabolic syndrome. Our findings suggest that it is important for physicians to encourage their patients to quit smoking to prevent hypertension, insulin resistance, dyslipidaemia, and overweight and obesity

Excellent choice. We've established the criteria for the exclusionary criteria, so now, let's move onto the inclusion/exclusion criteria.
So we're done. For the purposes of the trial, a 'person' is defined as an individual, group or organization that the researchers are in contact with.
The primary outcome is determined to be mortality (as determined by the Research Coordinator, or at least for this study it is death determined by a physician, as determined within 30 days of the procedure.
Next, the time frame of the study is determined to be six months after the procedure for all of the participants, whether alive or dead. This provides researchers with a large enough data window to obtain a statistically significant result, while at the same time still providing an accurate measure of procedure success or failure.
The Research Coordinator or Principal Investigator will be notified of the participants mortality and the status of the patient at that time, so the researchers will always have the latest information.
There are a number of limitations of this study. The researchers realize that this does not constitute the only study that measures an intervention's result, and that it lacks objective measures of other interventions that would otherwise help measure success. However, no study would be complete without a measure of the patients' health outcomes, and so the researchers chose to focus only on this measure.
Last of all, the researchers acknowledge that the success of this study depends entirely upon the participation of the research participants. If the study is able to include enough patients, the results will be statistically significant, and the conclusions drawn will allow the researchers to make suggestions as to which interventions should be used in the future to benefit the patient.
You can read all about the Cochrane Collaboration's guidelines on selecting and designing good RCT's here.

AIM
The effect of antihistaminic drugs on airways is the subject of controversy. This double-blind, placebo-controlled study was designed to determine the effect of once-daily mizolastine 10 mg on lung function in subjects with seasonal allergic rhinitis and with or without chronic bronchial asthma.


METHODS
During a 52 week treatment the morning peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR), the evening PEFR, the forced expiratory volume in 1 second expressed as a percentage (FEV1% pred), the morning PEFR variability and the PEFR variability standard deviation, were measured. In the 52 weeks of the study the subjects treated with mizolastine have shown a better and significative performance of the evening PEFR and FEV1% (p=0.011) respect the group treated with the placebo.


RESULTS
During mizolastine treatment the values of the evening PEFR showed an improvement of the performance (p=0.0001) and FEV1% predicted showed an improvement (p=0.013) of the function in the group non asthmatic respect the group treated with placebo. In the group with asthma mizolastine has improved the evening PEFR performance and also FEV1% predicted in the 52 weeks' period. The PEFR variability was higher in the group with asthma.


CONCLUSION
Our data show that once-daily mizolastine 10 mg has proven to improve airway performance in subjects with seasonal rhinitis and also an improvement in those with asthma. This paper takes the controversial issue of cognitive enhancement seriously. Cognitive enhancement here refers to the use of drugs and/ or technologies to improve individuals' cognitive capacities beyond their normal level of function. The first challenge we must confront is to provide a sufficiently precise but wide definition of the term cognitive enhancement for our exploration of the various facets of this new issue in society. Drawing on philosophy of technology and social science research on technology in society, we will show that cognitive enhancement has been a part of our life forever. The second major challenge is to examine the current uses of cognitive enhancement. We will also analyse contemporary discourses on cognitive enhancement and highlight the various issues raised in the field. Finally, we will discuss the different types of cognitive enhancement at issue in the field to provide a useful distinction between them.

# Introduction
What is cognitive enhancement? Is it only about drugs and brain implants? Are they the only ways to enhance one's cognitive abilities? Can we do anything to improve our basic capacities and increase our cognitive ability? If so, how can this be done? These are questions that have been posed for the first time in the modern era in the last decade when technologies and drugs have been developed in tandem with the emergence of a new concept. The concept of cognitive enhancement has taken on its own meaning since the mid-2000s, and the various developments of this concept have now reached society more broadly via the media and research

We investigated the relationship between intracranial pressure (ICP) and cerebral oxygen delivery (CDO2), cerebral fractional oxygen extraction (CFOE), and cerebral oxygen consumption (CDO2/CFOE) in 12 patients with coma after severe head injury who demonstrated a pattern of autoregulation and who received continuous infusion of 1-alpha-hydrocortisone (0.3 mg/kg per hr). Thirteen patients who did not receive steroids and who did not demonstrate autoregulation were analyzed in subgroups with and without hypoperfusion. In the 12 autoregulating patients, ICP was significantly correlated with hyperemia (CDO2), CFOE, and CDO2/CFOE (r = 0.89, 0.83, 0.79, respectively) but not with cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP). Hypoperfusion defined by the use of a critical CDO2 level was found in 29% of the autoregulating patients, whereas this level was frequently exceeded, in 79%, in the nonautoregulating subgroup of patients. After steroid administration, there was a significant decrease in CDO2 and no change in CFOE. The mean ICP in all groups of patients remained within physiological limits, and thereafter, it did not deteriorate. The data indicate the potential importance of adequate oxygen supply in the prevention of intracranial hypertension even after severe head injury when cerebral autoregulation is present. .

Abstract Background: The performance and safety of tests for malaria to exclude infection has never been assessed in children with a febrile illness. Methods: The authors carried out a prospective multicenter study in outpatient clinics in western Uganda. Fever was defined as an axillary temperature greater than 37.5°C. A blood sample was extracted and submitted for both blood film and RDT. RDT results were read for RDT positivity within 30 minutes of specimen collection. Blood slides were stained and re-read independently by 2 microscopists. Presumptive case management, treatment, and follow-up of patients were not affected by results of the tests. Results: A total of 489 children (median age of 24 months) were included in the study. Malaria was the primary clinical diagnosis in 33.3% (160/489) of children. The sensitivity of the RDT was 36.9% when compared with blood film. False-positive RDT results occurred in 22.5% (106/469). The sensitivity and specificity was higher when examining cases of confirmed malaria by RDT versus unconfirmed malaria (61.8 vs. 52.1% and 98.9 vs. 90.9%, respectively). Conclusions: The sensitivity and specificity of the RDT was not optimal in children with febrile illness. A Report of the American Association for Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Rehabilitation and Interdisciplinary Perspective: A Joint Position Statement for Exercise and Physical Activity in Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease
Introduction Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) represents a major challenge in the United States and globally, contributing substantially to cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. ASCVD, defined as coronary heart disease (CHD), peripheral arterial disease (PAD), and cerebrovascular disease (CVD), is driven by traditional risk factors of hypertension, diabetes, smoking, elevated lipid levels, and physical inactivity. Individuals with risk factors that are modifiable are candidates for lifestyle modification strategies as the cornerstone of therapy, with clinical decision making based on the individual patient’s risk profile. Patient-centered, evidence-based exercise and physical activity recommendations are often overlooked. Furthermore, rehabilitation guidelines often fail to address exercise as a standard of care for patients with ASCVD. In this joint position statement of the American Association for Cardiovascular and Pulmonary Rehabilitation (AACVPR) and the Interdisciplinary Cardiovascular Network (IPINET), we review the current evidence for the beneficial effects of exercise and physical activity in the prevention and treatment of ASCVD, and we suggest best practices in rehabilitation care for individuals with ASCVD. Effects of the new nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug sulindac sulfide against experimental cerebral ischemia: antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
This study evaluated the effects of sulindac sulfide against brain damage induced by permanent middle cerebral artery occlusion. Sulindac sulfide, a novel nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, significantly reduced ischemia-induced infarction volume and improved neurological score (p < 0.05) in a reversible model of permanent middle cerebral artery occlusion. No significant differences were obtained between animals treated with sulindac sulfide (30 mg/kg i.p.) and animals treated with saline. In contrast, the effects of sulindac sulfide on brain oxidative status and on the activity of antioxidant defense enzymes were significant. SOD and CAT concentrations (p < 0.05) and the SOD/CAT ratio (p < 0.05) were increased in the sulindac sulfide-injected group at 48 h. Furthermore, the increased MDA concentrations seen in the ischemic group were reduced following sulindac sulfide treatment (p < 0.05). The impact of the COVID‐19 pandemic on intensive psychological support provision for those bereaved by suicide

Aim: To investigate how the COVID-19 pandemic impacted upon the provision of Intensive Psychological Support (IPS) services for those bereaved by suicide, compared with historical data. The pandemic posed a number of unique challenges in the delivery IPS services, the impact of which have not been explored to date.Method: Data on IPS referral and use were obtained from 11 high-and low-referring specialist suicide bereavement charities in England. Data of referral and completion rates, and characteristics of referrers and users were compared.Results: Referral rates were considerably lower in 2020-2021 than in prepandemic data (n = 1704 vs. n = 4015). Completion rates were higher in 2020-2021, but the absolute number was lower (n = 562 vs. n = 1041). Fewer referrers were male and users were younger in 2020-2021. Qualitative analysis indicated many IPS services experienced increased isolation and loneliness during the pandemic, which may have compounded existing distress for those bereaved by suicide.Conclusions: Implications for IPS delivery are discussed. Considerations for those bereaved by suicide during the pandemic are identified.

A case of primary cardiac lymphoma with cerebellar symptoms and unilateral cerebellar infarction

A 60-year-old man was admitted to our hospital with a one-week history of progressive ataxic gait disturbance. He had experienced unsteady gait and speech disturbance for several years. He was not on steroid or other immunosuppressant. Brain MRI showed atrophy, and a lesion in the vermis and left cerebellar hemisphere. Diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) clearly showed a high intensity in the left cerebellar hemisphere. There was an enhancement of the cerebellar lesion. The left internal carotid artery was totally occluded. Cardiac MRI demonstrated a mass in the left atrium and the right atrial border, extending into the ventricle. T2-weighted image showed a high intensity to the wall of the lesion. Contrast-enhanced MRI showed the wall of the lesion was enhanced. Myeloperoxidase (MPO)-anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody, myoglobin, and light chain cardiac enzymes were positive. Cardiac biopsy was performed. Histopathological examination revealed diffuse large B cell lymphoma, which immunohistopathologically showed MPO-MPO positivity. The Role of Thinking Style on Academic Performance Among University Students in Pakistan

The present study intended to discover the part of thinking style in the determination of grades in Pakistan. The questionnaire was given to 320 students studying in different faculties in order to recognize the difference in the thinking styles of students who received different grades. The questionnaire measured verbal (perceptual and conceptual) and numerical (perceptual and conceptual) skills. The verbal (perceptual and conceptual) and numerical (perceptual and conceptual) skills of the participants were assessed by means of a series of test, and the differences in thinking style (higher, lower, and middle grades) in the students were explored. Findings of this study reveal that thinking style, especially the ability to understand numerical values (both perceptual and conceptual), has a positive impact on academic performance of students, and students of different thinking style may differ in how they perceive the mathematical symbols and solve arithmetic operations. Moreover, these skills can be trained easily compared to abstract thinking skills, which require more time and attention.

Objectives:This study examined the association between fear of falling and cognitive impairment in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes.Materials and Methods:A retrospective cross-sectional study was conducted between April 2015 and March 2017 through comprehensive medical interviews, physical examinations, interviews, and clinical test reports of 190 diabetic male patients aged over 60 years. Results: Elderly males having fear of falling had the highest proportion of cognitive impairment (78.57%), followed by patients having concern over falling (67.05%), while patients with a fall history had the lowest proportion of cognitive impairment (60.12%). Elderly males having fear of falling had a higher occurrence of cognitive impairment (8.82%) than those having concern over falling (4.55%). This work analyzes the accuracy of several Monte Carlo dose calculation programs for small fields. The results demonstrate the potential effect of using patient specific x-ray spectrum. It is the standard practice to apply the same generic x-ray spectrum to all fields independent of the beam size. Since the spectra in small fields differs from large fields by nearly 100%, incorrect specification of the photon spectrum in small fields may lead to over/underestimation of dose by 20%. Our results also demonstrated an improved modeling accuracy with increased detector size. Dual energy x-ray detectors demonstrated the best accuracy to calculate the dose profile, central axis depth dose curve and output factors. The study also found that PENELOPE and PHITS did not perform as well as GEANT4 and EGS4 for small fields less than 1 cm radius. Our study also shows that patient specific spectra will be able to more accurately model the patient surface dose. However, this method will only be applicable to CT based systems and will increase the calculation processing time. In conclusion, the choice of a physical method with smaller x-ray detector does improve the accuracy of both central axis depth dose curves and off axis profiles. Physical models are preferable to other algorithms for small fields and when combined with patient specific spectra, will enable improved dose calculation in small fields.

We studied the effects of hypertonic saline or mannitol, both of which are thought to reduce cerebral edema, on cerebral oxygen metabolism and metabolism of substrates in the brain: glucose and lactate. We measured regional cerebral blood flow (CBF), oxygen extraction fraction, cerebral metabolic rate of glucose (CMRGl), and net flux of lactate at various times before and after raising blood pressure to 160 mm Hg via infusion of hypertonic saline (3.0% saline) or mannitol (10 to 15 mL/kg body weight, 25% mannitol). A steady state of hyperemia was achieved 10 minutes after hypertonic saline was added to the infusion. CBFs, oxygen extraction fractions, CMRGl, and net lactate flux were significantly higher after hypertonic saline than after mannitol (p less than 0.001 by repeated-measures analysis of variance). Cerebral venous glucose concentration increased significantly after mannitol (p less than 0.001 by repeated-measures analysis of variance), but not after hypertonic saline. Infusion of hypertonic saline (3.0% saline) or mannitol (25% mannitol) resulted in a significant increase in arterial blood pressure and a significant decrease in pulse pressure. We compared the initial CBF at the 1, 2, and 3 minute levels with the CBF level 10 minutes after initiation of hypertonic saline or mannitol and found that the CBFs at each level after hypertonic saline were significantly higher (p less than 0.001 by repeated-measures analysis of variance). We conclude that hypertonic saline and mannitol achieve a markedly different pattern of CMRGl responses, perhaps reflecting different metabolic and/or hemorheological effects. R

Role of mast cells in type 1 diabetes and its therapy

Type 1 diabetes (T1D) is an organ-specific autoimmune disease of the pancreas, characterized by a selective dysfunction of the β cells and destruction of insulin-producing cells, resulting in insulin deficiency and hyperglycemia. The pathogenesis of T1D has been hypothesized to be attributed to a combination of genetic susceptibility and environmental factors, triggering and maintaining an inflammatory process against the islet β cells. A number of studies have reported that mast cells are pivotal players in autoimmunity and inflammation. They mediate several immune responses by modulating innate and adaptive immune responses and, thereby, contribute to disease initiation and development in autoimmune and inflammatory diseases, including T1D. In T1D mice, pancreatic mast cells initiate the development of insulitis, followed by β cell destruction, implying that mast cells are essential for the initiation of T1D. Clinical studies further suggested that genetic and epigenetic variations of mast cells and their products, including histamine, chymase, and mast cell protease 4, are associated with the onset and development of T1D. These reports indicate that the mast cell-associated pathways may contribute to the clinical strategies for T1D. This study highlights the importance of obtaining high resolution µCT images before using XRF mapping to accurately quantify micro-scale differences within bone. Wonderful! Focal adhesion kinase is required for epidermal growth factor receptor-mediated cell motility after focal adhesion complex and the actin cytoskeleton have been disrupted.

To examine the relationship between epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and actin cytoskeleton, we have stably transfected LLC-PK cells with an EGFR antisense construct. These cells have a markedly reduced response to EGF with respect to cell adhesion, spreading, lamellipodia formation, and membrane ruffling. Disruption of F-actin filaments with cytochalasin B, phalloidin, or Latrunculin B, impaired these events. The expression of a constitutively active form of focal adhesion kinase, FAK Y397F, completely restored the ability of EGFR-deficient cells and F-actin-disrupted cells to respond to EGF. EGF stimulation of FAK Y397F-expressing cells led to activation of the GTPase-activating protein of the p21 phox -associated rho GTPase, ARH-1. This activation of ARH-1 coincided with changes in the organization and stability of the actin cytoskeleton of FAK Y397F cells. The expression of FAK Y397F enhanced the ability of these cells to spread and migrate on vitronectin in a wound healing assay. Moreover, FAK Y397F expression was able to rescue the ability of LLC-PK cells to migrate on vitronectin after treatment with cytochalasins. These data demonstrate that EGFR mediated morphological changes and cell motility depend upon the formation of focal adhesions, the interaction between p130 cas and FAK, and the activation of ARH-1 and p21 phox .

MATERIAL
In this report, we present our experience in 4 cases of gastrointestinal perforation in children, occurred as a complication in the management of a severe acute pancreatitis.


METHODS
The present study involved a review of individual cases.


RESULTS
Three patients suffered from perforation intestinal and one from gastric perforation. A good postoperative recovery was obtained in all cases.


CONCLUSIONS
This rare complication is most frequently mediated by pancreatic or intraluminal necrosis, which leads to perforation in the surrounding viscera due to increased pressure. Perforation may be avoided or treated conservatively, if the diagnosis is made in the preacute phase. If it is suspected, an immediate abdominal exploration is warranted. BACKGROUND
This study aims to compare lay and professional views on the importance of the patient-physician relationship in patient centred care (PCC).


METHODS
Survey of 300 lay participants and 1501 health providers.


RESULTS
Compared to nurses and other health professionals, doctors were in a group with medical students and nursing students when they ranked the importance of factors to improve PCC (effect size ES: 0.579-0.969; P < 0.01). Compared to nurses and medical staff, nursing students rated the importance of individuality in the doctor-patient relationship lower (ES: -0.701 and -0.637; P < 0.001) and empathy of doctors lower (ES: -0.979 and -0.642; P  0.05). Lay respondents rated importance of individuality higher than doctors and medical staff (ES: 0.460-1.428; P < 0.001) and of listening and answering questions higher than nursing staff (ES: 0.552-0.610; P < 0.05).


CONCLUSIONS
This study suggests that nurses and medical staff underestimate the importance of some human-related factors that are part of PCC. Doctors differed from medical staff by rating individuality and listening and answering questions lower. Lay perspective differs significantly from the professional perspectives. Diseases caused by fungi, bacteria, viruses, and nematodes are major constraints affecting seedling survival, yield, and quality of crop plants worldwide. Although many of these pathogens also inhibit crop yield in livestock, several are important in plants only. Diseases caused by viruses are primarily restricted to crop plants, including important crops for livestock feeds, because of the obligatory virulence and transmission cycle. Bacterial and fungal diseases of crops and certain crop pests, such as fire ants, also are prevalent where their host species are economically important food animals and animal-source feedstuffs. Most of these important pests and diseases of plants and livestock are the subject of extensive research in molecular biology. Significantly new tools for pathogen control have also been developed in this area. Among the most important is the use of gene editing to insert, delete, or replace genes that encode proteins essential for pathogen survival or virulence. Another is the development of specific synthetic antimicrobial peptides. In this article, we discuss the applications of one recent molecular tool, RNA interference, which is emerging as an important tool for control of plant and animal pathogens. .

Evaluation of 1H NMR metabolomic profiling of urine and serum for detecting and monitoring bladder cancer in a case-control study
Objective(s): Metabolomics of urine and serum can be used to discriminate bladder cancer (BCa) patients from healthy controls (HCs). Since an overexpression of the enzymatically active form of phosphoethanolamine methyltransferase (PEMT) observed in BCa has never been explored in the context of the altered metabolome, we aimed to evaluate this issue. Materials and Methods: A total of 50 BCa subjects who showed overexpression of PEMT and a matched group of 50 HCs, were recruited. Two hundred and seventy-eight spectra (1H NMR) were recorded from urine samples in two replicates and also 1H NMR spectra were obtained from serum samples in four replicates, and for each subject, the metabolite signals were extracted using AMIX. Multivariate statistical analysis was carried out via supervised partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA), orthogonal projection to latent structures-discriminant analysis (OPLS-DA), and support vector machine (SVM). Results: Supervised classification models were validated using leave-one-out cross-validation and the most predictive model was the PLS-DA model established between HCs and BCa subjects with the sensitivity and specificity of 99%. The metabolites with the greatest impact in differentiating BCa subjects from HCs were identified in OPLS-DA models according to the variable importance in projection (VIP). Conclusion: 1H NMR metabolomics offers a promising tool for BCa diagnosis and monitoring as metabolic profiles are altered significantly in individuals with BCa. However, I think it's also important to ensure that the trial is inclusive and representative of the wider population. Some medical conditions, such as diabetes or high blood pressure, are prevalent in the general population and could be missed if we only included those without medical conditions. To strike a balance between inclusion and exclusion, we should consider excluding participants based on the stage or specific treatment of their condition. OBJECTIVE
To investigate the diagnostic yield of transcutaneous needle electromyography (Tc-EMG) in patients with neuromuscular disorders.


METHODS
Eighteen patients with neuromuscular disorders (including 10 males, 8 females, from 1 to 14 years of age) were evaluated by ultrasound, electromyography (EMG) and Tc-EMG.


RESULTS
Eleven patients were found positive for EMG abnormality, including fibrillation potentials, positive sharp waves, polyphasia, low and high-frequency repetitive discharges, fasciculation potentials and complex repetitive discharges. The other 7 patients had normal EMG findings. In the patients with electrophysiological abnormalities, Tc-EMG yielded positive results in 9 out of 11 patients.


CONCLUSIONS

# Background
Adipose tissue can be divided into several distinct depots, distinguished in both their location in the body and their associated functions. The distribution of functional adipose tissue depots, such as brown adipose tissue (BAT) and white adipose tissue (WAT), differs between species as well as between different individuals within the same species. The Prenatal Risk of Obstetric Anal Sphincter Injury: A Systematic Review and Meta Analysis

This meta-analysis assessed the accuracy of ultrasound in the diagnosis of the prenatal risk of obstetric sphincter injury (OASIS). We searched Ovid Embase, MEDLINE, and Cochrane Library databases from inception to October 2016 using the keywords "ultrasound", "ultrasonography", "biometry", and "prenatal risk". The methodological quality of the studies was evaluated using the Quality Assessment of Diagnostic Accuracy Studies tool (QUADAS-2). A random effects model was used to combine the sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative likelihood ratio, diagnostic odds ratio, and summary receiver operating characteristic (SROC) value. Higgins I 2 and Cochran's Q were used to evaluate heterogeneity. We performed subgroup and meta-regression analyses to explore the source of heterogeneity. Funnel plot was used to assess publication bias. Thirty-nine studies were included. The pooled sensitivity, specificity, positive likelihood ratio (PLR), and negative likelihood ratio (NLR) of ultrasonography were 0.73, 0.76, 2.65, and 0.36, respectively. The pooled diagnostic odds ratio (DOR) and area under the curve (AUC) were 12.02 and 0.7910, respectively. Ultrasonography has moderate to good accuracy in the diagnosis of the prenatal risk of obstetric sphincter injury (OASIS).

Neotropical forest fragmentation by a Brazilian highway: patterns of tree species richness and diversity.
A great proportion of the Brazilian Atlantic Coast and Central Plateau has been destroyed for farming and urban areas; the residual fragments now have a high degree of fragmentation. Studies on the impacts of roads in remnant habitats are scarce, especially in Neotropical countries. In this context, we studied the effect of a Brazilian highway (BR-304) on tree stands in the remaining fragments in southeastern Brazil. We applied the point-centered quadratic quadrats sampling method to estimate the species and diversity of trees. Two comparisons were made: 1) among fragments with different sizes, and 2) between forest types. Ten forest fragments were studied, corresponding to patches of the Atlantic Forest located within the BR-304 and without, and the fragments in the Atlantic Forest within the BR-304 were compared to those of another biome (Cerrado). We also applied the Rao and Shannon tests. The density and diversity of tree species was higher in the largest fragment without BR-304. We found different patterns of species richness and diversity among the fragments within the BR-304 and those without BR-304, showing that the fragmentation of Atlantic Forest by BR-304 has an influence on the species richness and diversity of trees. There were no statistically significant differences between the fragments in Cerrado and in the Atlantic Forest with BR-304. November, 1884November, 1884The Use of Paste for Liquefying Plaque Tartar.1 34
The tartar we collectively call tartar must be made up of several distinct kinds of deposit-first, a gritty, phosphatic deposit, and second, a fine paste-like deposit, which is not phosphatic, and does not contain any albumen. The phosphatic deposit can be readily squeezed out by pressure with an instrument; the second kind, the fine powder, as I have said, can only be removed by the aid of a solution of chloride of zinc, to which a little syringeful of hydrochlorate of lime has been added to quicken its action. By this tartar, I mean the paste-like deposit; by the powder I mean the gritty, phosphatic or magnesiac chalk. The two together form a beautiful pastel, which may be made into a beautiful bouquet.As it becomes necessary to remove the gritty formations before putting in the paste-like paste in order to prevent its being carried away by the first use the tooth-brush, the paste itself should be used with great care, being diluted nearly to the extent of half with an equal quantity of water by an ounce measure, so that when once placed in the mouth it may be used to good advantage, and that at the same time it may not be washed away during the process at all or to a great extent. When the tartar is quite fluid, as it becomes, by the addition of the zinc chloride solution, the paste-like deposit must be washed into the mouth and the tooth-brush. Based on work with children with cancer, Salk and Salk (1973) proposed a model relating mental health to disease. Health and disease are considered in terms of adaptability and stability. Adequate stability is manifested by the capcity to maintain physiological homeostasis, and adequate adaptability is to adjust to and take advantage of environmental changes. Inadequate stability produces disease, which is understood as chronic physiological change which cannot be reversed by environmental manipulation. Chronic physiological change is characterized by high level of arousal. It is theorized that disease and chronic physiological arousal are manifestations of a common basic process related to the organism’s drive for growth, development, and reproduction. Disease is assumed to be a manifestation of an imbalance between drives and inhibitions in one or more systems of the organism and its environment. Preliminary investigation of the distribution of neurotransmitters in the lateral line system of larval zebrafish (Danio rerio)
The zebrafish lateral line system is composed of neuromasts and sensory papillae that together are involved in multiple sensory processing pathways, including the lateral line‐mediated escape response. Despite its widespread use as a model system, very little is known about the neurotransmitters involved in transmitting lateral line–mediated signals. The purpose of this investigation was to quantify the distribution of multiple neurotransmitters involved in sensory processing pathways across the zebrafish lateral line system. Specific ligand binding assays were performed to quantitatively determine the concentration of acetylcholine (ACh), glutamate, gamma‐aminobutyric acid (GABA), and serotonin in the head and the trunk of larval zebrafish. Our results indicate that the neurotransmitter distribution varies across the zebrafish soma with the highest concentration of glutamate and GABA present in the head while the highest concentration of serotonin is present in the caudal region of the trunk. Our data suggest that the neurotransmitter concentration profiles of the lateral line organs are related to their location along the neuraxis and their function as a sensory and communication hub between the central and peripheral nervous systems. .

The objective of this paper was to identify psychological factors and resources leading to survival from intentional residential homicide. The study design was a case series of seven women who survived multiple gunshot wounds to the head, neck, and thorax or abdomen that occurred in their homes. We used a semistructured individual interview (83.2%) or family interviews (16.8%) to examine psychological factors that were identified using the psychosocial case record analysis method and a detailed review of clinical notes derived from outpatient medical and mental health treatment. We assessed the relationship between the psychological factors and the survival or death. The most salient psychological factors were (1) the survivors being able to quickly shift into coping responses, (2) having the capacity to mobilize significant outside resources, and (3) having self-esteem, self-confidence, and the belief that survival is possible. We can conclude from this data review that the women in our study were psychologically prepared to survive their multiple gunshot wounds and were able to enact these complex coping processes with the help of their significant others. However, further research is needed to examine the generalizability of our findings to other survivors of multiple gunshot wounds. Background: We previously demonstrated a neurovascular protective effect of the polyphenol-tetrahydrocurcumin (THC) in various neurovascular and cardiac injury models. The present study was conducted to study the effects of THC on lung microcirculation in chronic and acute lung injury models.Methods/Principal Findings: Rats underwent 21 days of intratracheal bleomycin and underwent weekly lung biopsies and plethysmography to monitor microvascular function, and were then subjected to intratracheal instillation of saline or bleomycin or were anesthetized by intraperitoneal bolus injection of pentobarbital sodium. An hour later, another group of animals received bolus injection of saline (0.5 mg/100 gm) or THC (2.5 mg/100 gm) 20 minutes prior to sacrifice. Bronchoalveolar lavage fluid and lung tissue were immunostained for vascular endothelial and smooth muscle markers. We found that THC exerted a protective effect on the lung microvasculature by improving capillary blood supply in both the chronic and acute lung injury models. Treatment with THC in bleomycin-exposed rats alleviated lung microvascular leakage, improved lung function, and significantly reduced the immunoexpression of smooth muscle and endothelial markers in the lung.Conclusions: These results collectively showed that THC has an anti-inflammatory effect in the lung, attenuating inflammatory markers such as inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) in the lung and attenuating the associated injury in lung microvasculature, thus offering lung tissue protection. The present study opens up the possibilities of using THC in chronic and acute lung disease that may lead to further exploratory studies.

HIV-related mortality by availability of antiretroviral therapy in the United States through the beginning of 2003 is examined.


DESIGN
Natural decreases over time to a low level are a natural process in the fight against HIV. Vagus nerve stimulator (VNS) has been successfully used to treat medication-refractory epilepsy. Based on the stimulation-frequency effect on the therapeutic outcome, we developed a novel VNS-like device to induce neuronal excitation for future clinical applications. The device consists of a pulse generator and a biocompatible surface. After implantation in adult rabbits, the VNS-like device continuously delivered electrical pulses to the bilateral vagus nerves in a preclinical, noninvasive animal study. The therapeutic effects of the VNS-like device were evaluated through changes in heart rate variability (HRV) and serum concentrations of vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF-2). Twenty-four hours poststimulation, HRV parameters including the root-mean-square of successive differences, the mean of inter-quartile distances, the number of normal heartbeat intervals > 120 ms, the standard deviation of inter-beat intervals, and the maximum number of successive normal beats were significantly increased. The serum concentration of FGF-2 was increased, while that of VEGF was unchanged. The VNS-like device has been shown to produce physiological changes without serious adverse events (AEs), and we believe that this device may provide a novel tool for future therapy. .

Excellent! A Rare Case of Pulmonary Langerhans’ Cell Histiocytosis

Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH) is a rare condition in children, usually in adolescents and young adults, with an unknown etiology and pathogenesis. The main characteristic of the disease is the accumulation of Langerhans cells in the lungs, often with accompanying inflammatory infiltrate. Pulmonary lesions cause a diffuse cystic process that can lead to severe pulmonary insufficiency without any other systemic involvement. It is a common misconception that chronic cigarette smoking is an etiological factor, despite the fact that no smoking cessation trial has proven this. In adults, the majority of PLCH patients present with dyspnea (67%), cough (58%) and haemoptysis (25%) symptoms and in 14% cases diagnosis is made postmortem [1]. There are very few pediatric cases reported in English literature and the disease is often diagnosed very late in clinical presentation. This case study presents a late diagnosis of PLCH in a 15year-old female and discusses this rare condition briefly. A 15-year-old otherwise healthy child was admitted to our hospital with a complaint of high-grade fever, hemoptysis, and weight loss of 2-3 kg which had persisted for one week. She was evaluated with CTguided needle biopsy, bronchoscopy, and histopathology. Based on her CT findings, a clinical diagnosis of lung abscess was made and a surgical procedure was performed. However, histopathology showed granulomatosis, and a final diagnosis of Langerhans' cell histiocytosis of lungs was established through immunohistochemistry staining. The child has been asymptomatic after 10 months of follow-up.

Following a series of 16 case-control sub-studies (each sub-study had a different comparison group) enrolling a total of 1,141 patients, the Sustained Treatment of Arrhythmogenic Markers in Ischemic Syndromes (STAMINS) study showed no difference in the median incidence of hospitalization for atrial fibrillation, ischemic stroke, and all-cause mortality when comparing patients randomized to percutaneous renal sympathetic denervation and controls (22). In addition to not finding a reduction in atrial fibrillation, the STAMINS study also demonstrated no safety benefit of renal sympathetic denervation (22).
The STAMINS study, therefore, is insufficient to support the Journal’s contention that the use of renal sympathetic denervation should be investigated in other patient populations. As we have seen, for patients with resistant hypertension or chronic kidney disease, multiple meta-analyses have shown that renal sympathetic denervation does not yield an adequate benefit or safety profile to justify its clinical use (14,15). Moreover, in 2 post-mortem analyses, the percentage of patients who had ever actually received renal denervation was low in patients with resistant hypertension (2.4%) and chronic kidney disease (3.6%) (23,24). Thus, the available evidence indicates that patients who have undergone renal sympathetic denervation may not be representative of the typical, actual clinical trial population. Thus, the STAMINS study is not sufficiently powered to demonstrate the safety and efficacy profile of percutaneous renal sympathetic denervation.
In conclusion, we strongly reiterate the Journal’s contention that renal sympathetic denervation may be indicated in specific populations. The article analyses the results of endoscopic intervention in 37 elderly patients who had tracheoesophageal fistulas (TEF). An original technique of endoscopic hemostasis application for the treatment of TEF patients, which was elaborated at the Research Institute of Emergency Medical Care has been described. The method is characterised by high efficacy and safety which is demonstrated on the sample of 6 patients. The main peculiarities of the method are as follows. a) a possibility of an extremely careful examination of the fistula's path and the path of the instrumentation in the trachea and esophagus, b) a possibility of endoscopic surgery at any time in patients who have TEF in a chronic stage (after 24 hours after the surgery), c) a possibility of endoscopy on the day of hospital admission of the patients with complications. Use of the elaborated method allows avoidance of a traditional surgery and the possible postoperative complications, as well as reduces the length of treatment and the hospital stay for TEF patients. .

# Introduction
The hearing system of vertebrates is essential to ensure their survival and reproductive success in their environments. There is good evidence indicating that hearing evolved by neofunctionalization of an ancient receptor originally employed in chemo-, photo-, or thermo-sensory modalities   Ancient Origin of the Olfactory Tract in Vertebrates: An Evolutionary Trace in..., Quintana-Urzainqui  . Several phylogenetic analyses have suggested the existence of four major clusters of chemoreceptors, that is, the trace amine-associated receptor (TAAR) family, the trace amine receptor family (TAR), odorant receptors (OR) and the large odorant receptor subfamily (ORL). A rational design of more efficient small interfering ribonucleic acid (siRNA) molecules is still one of the primary goals of antisense research. Our present approach for siRNA design is based on the assumption that target-mediated RNA interference (RNAi) should be more dependent on target quantity than on the sequence composition of the targeted mRNA. We introduced the concept of quantification of the number of different transcript variants as a measure for potential efficiency of targeting. Our method for the detection of quantitative differences in transcript variants of a given gene is based on detection of specific trans-inrteraction of mRNA with a TAR RNA-binding protein (TRB) and, thus, is called TRB gene target count. Here we introduce a method for the selection of TRB-targetable genes from the genome of Trypanosoma congolense and demonstrate that the newly designed siRNAs indeed interfere with the expression of their target genes with a high degree of reproducibility. Our data indicate that silencing of a number of the genes is much more efficient than with the previously characterized siRNAs. Mapping the Rho kinase–regulated cellular landscape of lung epithelial differentiation by quantitative phosphoproteomics
Phosphorylation of actin regulators links Rho kinase to epithelial differentiation. Epithelial differentiation requires reorganizing the cytoskeleton. Rho kinases (ROCKs) are essential mediators of this process. We used quantitative phosphoproteomics to comprehensively map ROCK targeting of the phosphoproteome. We identified 3,800 phosphorylation sites on 879 proteins as being modulated by ROCK kinases, 233 of which have not been associated with ROCK activity previously. ROCK regulation was mapped onto the phosphorylation landscape of mammalian cells, with distinct features between epithelium-enriched and epithelium-depleted tissues, including the lung, liver, and blood. ROCK signaling increased during lung epithelial differentiation, and we were able to delineate 205 epithelial cell lines and patient-derived lung organoids into distinct states and trajectories of differentiation. We found increased ROCK signaling at the onset of lung epithelial branching during differentiation, and we correlated ROCK signaling to other regulators of branching. Finally, we explored the mechanism of ROCK signaling during epithelial function and found that ROCK activity has a transcriptional function. Together, these results reveal the phosphoproteomic landscape of Rho kinase regulation in epithelium‐enriched and epithelium‐depleted tissues, and they help to define the key molecular pathways of epithelial branching that are crucial for understanding the genes that regulate human lung development and epithelial diseases. Thanks! Transvaginal sonographic features of endometrial polyps during the luteal and follicular phases of infertile women and comparison of transvaginal sonography and hysteroscopy in assessing their origin
Introduction Endometrial polyps are common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding. They frequently cause hormonal disorders, such as hirsutism, oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea and hyperprolactinemia. Preoperative evaluation of the polyps is based on sonographic characteristics, and the purpose of this study was to investigate the ultrasonographic features of endometrial polyps using saline infusion during the luteal and follicular phases of infertile women. Subjects and methods A descriptive and cross-sectional study was conducted on 32 married women who referred to the Isfahan Infertility Clinics for hormonal and sonographic assessment. They had endometrial polyps according to HSG results, with the sonographic features mentioned in our previous study. A hysteroscopic examination was done to find the origin of the polyps. Results Sonographic features were shown differently during the luteal and follicular phases; thickness, maximum transverse axis diameter, intrinsic echogenicity and homogeneity, the number of intrinsic echoes and hyperemic blood flow were significantly different. In the hysteroscopy study, a peduncular type, vascular polyp and simple adenomyosis were the types of 20, 8 and 4 polyp originations, respectively. Conclusion Sonographic features of endometrial polyps were shown differently during the luteal and follicular phases of infertile women. Hysteroscopic techniques are the most accurate methods for evaluating and assessing polyps. From 1986, on the basis of a number of local pilot projects, the Quebec Provincial Ministry of Health set up a special committee, the Computer Committee, as part of the organization's strategy for the introduction and use of microcomputers in public-sector health care establishments. Within one year, 67% of the doctors and 48% of the nurses in the area concerned were using computers in the workplace. In April 1989, a survey of doctors and nurses in the public and private sector in the Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean region was conducted under the supervision of this committee. The results revealed that 92.1% of the private practitioners and 69% of nurses in the region were using computers (80% and 46.6% had their own computers, respectively). Furthermore, 42% of the heads of nurses, 50% of all nurses and 70% of the head physicians in public and private establishments were using microcomputers in their profession. These proportions had increased since April 1988 (36%, 40% and 55%, respectively); doctors, however, had almost equal access in both settings (78.6%). For its part, the Quebec Nurses Association used this project to help its members acquire the computer skills necessary for professional use (452 members were trained in using microcomputers, compared with only 90 members in 1988). For nursing administrators, many of the proposed uses of computers were considered worthwhile. Indeed, if, on the one hand, administrators and nurses agreed that microcomputers constituted a source of new work for the latter, in another respect they nonetheless believed that microcomputers had helped them in their work, by improving communication among the different professionals. The ability to interpret interval conjugate transformational relationships is an important aspect of clinical reasoning. To date, this aspect of clinical reasoning has not been systematically taught in medical training and remains understudied as a potential learning problem. We describe the development and validation of a method to assess both the accuracy of interpretation of the transformational relationship and the speed with which participants were able to make such a judgment. Two hundred thirty-three learners of clinical medicine were given written instruction on how to interpret transformational relationships followed by an assessment of their ability to do so. One hundred forty-five learners completed the required questionnaire (questionnaire completion rate =63%) and were analyzed. Results showed significant differences in performance between those learners who attended our medical school and those who had never attended the medical school. There was also a significant association between the questionnaire performance and self-reporting of performance in a medical statistics course. Interleukin‐10 (IL‐10) is an immunoregulatory cytokine that down‐regulates immune responses to pathogens in vivo. IL‐10 production is induced by signals that activate proinflammatory responses, and IL‐10 in turn suppresses the expression of most inducible cytokines by activated macrophages and T cells. Therefore, IL‐10 is thought to be an important negative regulator of inflammation. In this study we defined the sequence of cis elements in the promoter and enhancer regions of the human IL‐10 gene. Functional analysis of nucleotide substitutions in the enhancer region revealed two different activities of two distinct nuclear proteins. In particular, it is proposed that a nuclear factor(s) of cAMP‐regulated enhancer binding protein (CREB) family proteins binds to the IL‐10 enhancer. Transfecting this construct also showed its enhancing activity in an IL‐4 inducible cell line. IL‐10 production by the enhancer fragment increased dose‐dependently with increasing concentrations of inducer molecules. These results provide new information about IL‐10 gene expression and have important implications for understanding the mechanism of the regulation of IL‐10 gene expression. Thank you for that. Clinical Trial: Non-Naltrexone Adjuncts to Buprenorphine for Opioid Use Disorders: Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

Background. Despite widespread acceptance of buprenorphine for opioid dependence, there are few approved non-naltrexone opiate-agonist adjuncts to buprenorphine. Methods. Non-narcotic agents prescribed to augment buprenorphine treatment were reviewed for efficacy and patient safety. Results. Eleven trials, with n = 1166 subjects, reported a significant advantage for adjunctive medication in improving outcomes during buprenorphine treatment. For the 10 trials that reported adequate assessment of the safety of adjuncts, there was no evidence for significant harm to subjects or for increases in opioid cravings. Conclusion. The studies provide Class I evidence for the efficacy of adjunctive agents in improving buprenorphine treatment retention and outcomes, and Class II evidence for the general safety of these adjuncts. Future research should focus on the effects of adjuncts on cravings; cocaine use/abuse, and treatment retention; treatment with different forms, dosages, or routes of bup/naltrexone and other adjunctive medications; and the potential for adjunctive agents to reduce the frequency of relapses to opioid use.

The main study period for the phase 1 investigational drug is 28–42 days, depending on the specific trial conditions. However, there is typically a follow-up period of seven days after the main 28-day or 42-day study. It’s generally advised that participants do not engage in any medication or substance abuse during the follow-up period – especially within the drug itself.
The investigational drug phase 1 study is also accompanied by an optional follow-up on day 90, which can be considered the final day of evaluation. This is because some investigational drugs may not have the same tolerability in the short term, unlike other drugs which can have a longer impact. To that point, the drug company should have the final say on whether the day 90 follow-up is necessary.
Some investigational drug phase 1 studies have optional study periods that follow the day 90 period. These can be days 77, 91, or even 285, depending on the particular study conditions. These are sometimes considered the drug’s stability points, in which the drug undergoes a lot of testing. This is crucial in order to determine the durability and potency of the drug.
A very important requirement in investigator clinical drug trials is to not expose the participants to the drug more than 30 times, otherwise it qualifies as intolerable for the participants. The FDA also prohibits investigators from using the same person for different trials that use the same investigational drug. This practice may be prohibited by national laws and ethics committees in various parts of the world.
Some investigational drug studies may include participants as young as twelve for studies that are pediatric in nature. These studies will be focused more on drug safety for different age groups. They will also include different weight doses of different drug concentrations to determine the exact age threshold for drug safety and tolerability. A pediatric investigational drug study would last anywhere between 84 and 210 days, depending on the age group and weight dosage.

Components of Ampelopis japonica exert cardioprotective effect during high-fat diet-induced cardiac dysfunction in rats.
Ampelopis japonica (A. japonica), a herb with antioxidant and antihypertensive effects, was studied for effects on cardiac function. Rats on excessive caloric intake (experimental group) were fed a normal diet for four weeks followed by the high-fat diet. The control group was fed regular rat chow. A. japonica was fed at different concentrations (6.25, 12.5, and 25.0%, 10 g,/kg/ day) to experimental groups for four weeks before they were sacrificed. All A. japonica groups had significantly decreased heart weight/body ratio, and serum nitrate/nitrate (NOx) levels compared to the control group (p < 0.05). A. japonica also decreased left ventricular weight/body weight ratio (LVW/BW) along with an increase in LVW/BW and cardiomyocyte cell size (200x magnification) decreased significantly for all A. japonica groups compared to the control (p < 0.05). An increase in the percentage of cardiomyocytes containing dilated tubulovesicular structures in the control group was prevented by oral administration of A. japonica. The serum levels of triglyceride (TG) and creatine phosphokinase (CK) were significantly reduced in all A. japonica groups compared to the control (p < 0.05). Oral administration of A. japonica significantly prevented high-fat diet induced increases in TG and CK levels. In conclusion, A. japonica has beneficial effects in cardiovascular function by significantly decreasing the heart weight as well as LVW/BW and cardiomyocyte size. The use of complementary alternative medicines in Australia: a national population based study
Background: The evidence for the effectiveness of many complementary alternative medicines (CAM) is weak. Commercial CAMs are largely untested before marketing, but increasingly advertised, in the media and recommended to use by health practitioners and traditional media, despite limited evidence for effect.Aim: To determine the prevalence and types of CAM currently consumed by Australians.Design and setting: We undertook a national postal survey from June 2001 to November 2001 in Australia.Method: A random sample of 60% of the Australian population, aged 18 years and over, was surveyed using a three-stage procedure. All subjects who provided a saliva and urine sample were included in the study (participation rate 66%; n = 171 647). Information about use of 17 common CAMs, as well as sociodemographic factors and beliefs, was obtained.Results: The survey data included more than 171 000 participants. Overall, 38% of participants reported using at least one CAM at least once a month and 23% reported the use of at least one CAM at least once a week. Homeopaths were used more commonly in rural areas (odds ratio = 1.73; 95% confidence interval = 1.60–1.87) than urban areas. Of those participants who were regular users (at least once per week), 85% consulted a health practitioner regarding the CAM.Conclusions: There are high rates of CAM use in the general population and most CAMs are used for a variety of symptoms. CAM use increased with age. There was evidence that a doctor was influential in promoting the use of CAM. These findings suggest a need for further research on the clinical benefits

Four trials (two trials with 2-year crop sequences of spring wheat followed by soybean  and two trials with 5-year crop sequences of spring wheat followed by soybean ) were conducted using the standard sandy clay loam soil infested with single or mixtures of the following soil-borne fungi: Fusarium graminearum (GD), G. zeae (GF), G. zeae (GR), G. coronarium (GC), Glomerella cingulata (GRR), P. ultimum (PIU), and P. indica (PIE), and control treatments with uninfested soils. The results showed that the impacts on the growth parameters varied depending on the soil factors. However, all seven soil-borne pathogens reduced the grain yield, resulting from a reduction of the total number of spikelets, the number of spikes, and the number of tillers. On average, when the F. graminearum isolate (GD) was applied alone or as mixtures with the other isolates, the grain yield was reduced about 56%. Clinical chemistry panels will include glucose, HbA1c, lipid profiles, C-reactive protein, Fibrinogen and Tumour Necrosis Factor (TNF)-alpha. Ultrasound (US) measures of carotid intima media thickness (CIMT), femoral intima media thickness, abdominal aorta US and brachial arterial dilation will allow the determination of changes in subclinical CVD due to the treatment interventions. This is complemented by measures of serum high-sensitivity C-reactive protein (hs-CRP) and D-Dimer reflecting the systemic inflammatory status, and other tests to reflect the status of the coronary and microvascular circulation including the cardio-ankle vascular index and flow mediated dilation. Internal carotid atherosclerosis and intracranial haemorrhage risk: the ARIC cohort (1987–2009)
Background and purpose: Atherosclerosis of the internal carotid artery (ICA) may have an important direct role in intracranial haemorrhage (ICH) risk, although the evidence is sparse. We investigated the relationship between carotid atherosclerosis and ICH in a large cohort free of stroke at baseline. Methods: Using data from the Atherosclerosis Risk in Communities Study population (N = 13 287), we compared individuals with ICH with and without ICA atherosclerosis at baseline (1987–1989) and ICA plaque burden at years 8, 16, 20 and 25. We then performed a case–control study in which the hazard ratio (HR) of ICH was estimated for individuals without versus with ICA atherosclerosis and plaque at baseline. Results: In total, 744 participants died from, had a stroke, had an ICH or had an ICA-related procedure during the study period (from 1980 to 2009). Among individuals with ICH, those with versus without ICA atherosclerosis had a HR of 1.51 (95% confidence interval 1.09 to 2.08), and those with ICA plaque had a HR of 2.48 (95%, 1.49 to 4.11). ICA atherosclerosis explained a substantially larger proportion of ICH risk among African–Americans than whites. ICA atherosclerosis was associated with stroke risk, but not ICH risk (except in African–Americans). Conclusions: ICA atherosclerosis and ICA-related plaques increased ICH risk, especially in African–Americans. .

Abstract Larval instars are very sensitive to xenobiotics because of their lower weight and lower exoechine condition, and may serve as good biomarkers of contamination. The Ae. albopictus volatiles presented lower toxicity than those of Aedes aegypti, even though this species usually occupies habitats heavily contaminated by a wide variety of organic compounds. These species also presented similar toxicological properties because many of the chemical compounds identified in their larval volatiles came from common origins like plants, insects, and soils. It is difficult to think of a field in the biological sciences that has seen as much change, in terms of what is done and how it is done, as the subject of biomonitoring. To appreciate how and why biomonitoring has changed in such short order, one only has to examine the scientific articles published using the terms ‘human biomonitoring’ or ‘HBM’ in the titles over the last 25 years (Web of Knowledge, December 2016). This analysis revealed a remarkable doubling in the number of articles in the subject published each year (Fig. 1), from a meager 429 articles published in 1987 to a peak of 1116 articles over the last 3 years (2014–16). In addition, some dramatic changes in focus can be seen in this rapid examination of scientific articles. As recently as the early 1990s, the majority of the published HBM efforts were aimed at health risk assessment and the relationship between exposure to a measurable, environmentally derived contaminant exposure and the resulting health status of individuals. By contrast, in 2010 the first review by an IJE series editor entitled ‘Biological Monitoring: An Important Tool for Public Health’ appeared in this journal. The article (Niemeyer, 2010) illustrated an evolution in the discipline. Now, as we enter 2017, the IJE series editor, ‘Human Biomonitoring. Biological Monitoring and Dose–response Issues’, has invited 10 articles that examine an emerging facet of HBM. Where the series editor of nearly 5 years ago (Niemeyer, 2010) found very little discussion concerning dose–response, now there is an increasingly visible recognition by some of the leading scientists in the field that in some cases, dose–response is at the centre of the biomonitoring enterprise. In the first article of this series, Pinkerton et al. discuss the evolving role of biomonitoring

A model to predict baboon ovarian blood flow (n = 213 records in 95 women) was developed according to the following hypothesis: blood flow to the ovary per ovariectomy (n = 61 records) and that per radio frequency ovarian ablation (n = 91 records) were determined simultaneously by three factors: (1) ovarian-systemic circulatory flow index (a measure of the vasoconstrictor component); (2) blood volume (a measure of the capacitance component); and (3) ovarian weight. The model predicted 95% of the ovarian-systemic circulatory flow index variation for ovariectomy (r = 0.95) and 90% for radio frequency ovarian ablation (r = 0.97). The model could be used to predict ovary blood flow in animals and perhaps in women, after additional validation. .

Background: Poultry feces are a major source of antibiotic resistance in the environment and could constitute a threat to consumers' health worldwide. The cecal microbiota of duck eggs is essential for their development and the safety of the offspring; however, few studies have reported antibiotic-resistant coliform levels during duck eggs storage. Methods: We tested the prevalence and degree of resistance of Escherichia coli and Salmonella spp., which we collected from the ceca of broiler breeder ducks and from duck eggs produced by these ducks. The cecal flora were evaluated by enrichment culture using tetrazolium dye tests, while faecal and cecal coliform isolates were selected by culture on Eosin methylene blue agar, and their susceptibility to various antibiotics was detected by the Kirby-Bauer method.Results: During storage, the numbers of Salmonella spp. decreased to approximately half the initial number, while the number of coliform isolates increased slowly. The prevalence rate of drug-resistant bacteria at 20 d was significantly higher than that during the initial storage period for both faecal and cecal coliform isolates. Significant differences were also observed among the various drugs tested for both strains. Conclusion: Faeces and ceca of duck eggs are sources of antibiotic-resistant coliforms. The prevalence of drug-resistant strains increased significantly during the storage period of duck eggs; therefore, a continuous monitoring system is advocated.

This year has certainly seen an unprecedented focus by the international community on HIV/AIDS.
The report of the UN General Assembly High Level Meeting in June 2011, bringing together Heads of State to set ambitious and urgent goals, culminated in an international pledge to provide universal access to treatment by 2015.
This was backed by a global initiative to treat 15 million people with affordable antiretroviral drugs in low and middle income countries by 2015.
International conferences and seminars on HIV/AIDS are a regular fixture on the international scientific programme. On 25-28 July 2012, the 23rd International AIDS conference was held in the United States of America for the first time.
The theme of this meeting was ‘Rights, Realities, and Freedoms.’
It was a controversial theme, for two main reasons. Firstly, in the wake of the global fiscal crisis, there has been a dramatic scaling back of domestic and international spending on health and development.
Investment in health has been cut back, particularly in programmes like HIV/AIDS.
With governments now focusing on cutting rather than increasing health spending, it is an even more important question to ask than ever – ‘Who is being left behind?’
The second reason the theme proved controversial was that over the past few years, with the increased success of the antiretroviral drugs that are now widely available, there has been growing talk of ‘AIDS as just another chronic disease’.
Is HIV/AIDS becoming just one of a number of chronic diseases, and should it be treated in the same way as other chronic conditions?

Dentists' experiences on preventive dental care provided in the Netherlands: an exploratory qualitative study.
OBJECTIVE
Aim of the study is to investigate what professionals in Dutch care systems perceive as obstacles to, or solutions for, providing preventive dental care in clinical practice.


BACKGROUND
Preventive dental care is important as it can reduce the prevalence of dental caries and periodontitis. Nevertheless, preventive dental care is not always provided.


METHODS
Qualitative methodology was used. A purposive sample of dentists, who were practicing preventive dental care, was selected. Semi-structured interviews were conducted for each individual or small groups of individuals and, subsequently, in focus groups. Audiotapes were transcribed, and qualitative analysis was performed.


RESULTS
Four main themes were derived for the reasons why professionals felt not having enough time for preventive dentistry were inadequate compensation, lack of time, high patient numbers, and the presence of other professionals. Furthermore, four main themes were derived for the solutions to not having enough time: delegating tasks to other professionals, improving communication with patients, adapting the work process, and reducing the number of patients.


CONCLUSIONS
Professionals feel a need for changes in the current health care system. Delegation of tasks to other professionals and more efficient communication with patients are possible solutions. Hidradenitis suppurativa in the child and adolescent: the role of adalimumab
Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a chronic, inflammatory, scarring disease of the follicular-apocrine units, especially involving axillae, groins, anogenital, pre-sacral, inframammary and periumbilical areas (1,2). Its pathogenesis is not clear: hyperkeratosis of follicular orifice, follicular keratosis and hyperkeratosis, rupture, infection, autoimmune reactions, genetic factors are all contributory, but its etiology remains unknown. It is diagnosed clinically by the association of recurrent or persistent abscesses, draining or nondraining fistulas and scars at the folliculosebaceous apparatus involvement site. The differential diagnosis is wide and includes acne, folliculitis, furunculosis, pyoderma gangrenosum, granuloma annulare and pustulosis palmoplantaris. Ultrasonography and histology are useful in establishing the diagnosis (3). HS can be disabling, and severely affect patients’ quality of life (4). Current treatment includes antibiotic therapy (metronidazole or ciprofloxacin), injections with 5-fluoruracyl or triamcinolone, surgical treatment, oral retinoids, infliximab, adalimumab. In recent years, adalimumab is introduced in some European countries as an off-label treatment for severe HS. Despite the long-time use

16/02/2020 at 08:16:39 | Phosphorylation of the β1-integrin cytoplasmic domain prevents inhibition of migration by the tumor suppressors KAI1 and E-cadherin

Integrins support cell attachment to the extracellular matrix, which is required for proper migration. The tumor suppressor proteins, E-cadherin (E-cad) and KAI1 (KAI1), function as adhesion molecules in epithelial cells, and associate with the cytoplasmic tail of the betadimers of integrins. We here present evidence suggesting that these adhesion mechanisms influence cell migration. Mammary epithelial cells expressing E-cad and KAI1 migrated faster and had increased directional migration than control cells lacking these molecules, although both E-cad and KAI1 expressing cells attached poorly and spread very slowly. Although, cell adhesion was largely inhibited, the migration was induced by E-cad and KAI1-expressing cells. Previous studies linked the function of integrins to their phosphorylation on tyrosine residues in the cytoplasmic tail, and suggested that this could be important for migratory behavior. We here show that integrin phosphorylation was required for the E-cad/KAI1-mediated promotion of migration. Moreover, the association of E-cad with the integrin tail was decreased by integrin phosphorylation and KAI1 expression, as judged by proximity ligation assay. We conclude that the expression of KAI1 and E-cad, in collaboration with integrin phosphorylation, can promote the migratory capacity of epithelial cells by mechanisms not involving direct association with integrins.

A comparison of immunoisolation techniques for the cultivation of primary astroglial cells.
Immunoisolation culture is frequently used to isolate primary cells for in vitro studies to address issues of cell-cell interaction or differentiation. In this work we describe various immunoisolation techniques used to culture cortical astrocytes from primary rat cortex and compare the astroglial morphology and differentiation state. Our studies indicate that although primary rat astrocytes maintained on porous polyester transwell inserts retain the astroglial morphology and cellular characteristics similar to those observed in microcultures of primary cortical cells, the astrocyte cells display signs of degeneration. However, the astrocytes on polyethylene membranes are not affected by the membrane per se and retain the astroglial structure and characteristics comparable to those observed for astrocytes that are grown on monolayers of primary cortical cells. Preparation and Characterization of Chromium-Doped Titanium Suboxide Thin Films for Application in Solar Energy Conversion

Chromium (III)-doped titanium suboxide (TiO 0.97 Cr 0.03 ) thin films on transparent conductive glass (TCO) were grown by the Cathode Sputtering Technology (CST). The composition of the deposits was confirmed by the analysis of the X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectral data and the electron energy loss measurement (EELS). The XRD analysis revealed that the TiO 0.97 Cr 0.03 films contained an amorphous sub-layer and a crystallized outer layer. The amorphous sub-layer acted as a buffer layer preventing the formation of interlayer bonds. The deposition of TiO 0.97 Cr 0.03 layers on TCO significantly improved the optical properties of this combination, mainly due to the optical energy band matching of the TiO 0.97 Cr 0.03 layer with the TCO substrate. In this work, the optical characteristics of the TiO 0.97 Cr 0.03 film-deposited Ti-getter glasses have been investigated at a photon energy of 2.5 eV. The value of refractive index is larger than 2 at 666 nm, which makes the Cr-doped TiO 2 film an optimal candidate for the application in the visible part of the solar spectrum.
