Influence of Hydrogel Drug Delivery Vehicles on Fibrin Glue Properties

The influence of various hydrogel drug delivery vehicles on fibrin glue properties was investigated. Fibrin glue was prepared by mixing fibrinogen and thrombin at ratio of 21:1 (w/w). The study included six formulations: FS -fibrin glue (negative control), FS-C -fibrin glue with 1% carbopol (C), FS-CG -fibrin glue with 2% carbopol + 1% glycerol (CG), FS-CE -fibrin glue with 2% carbopol + 0.1% echinacea extract (CE), FS-CL -fibrin glue with 2% carbopol + 4% licorice extract (CL), FS-CR -fibrin glue with 2% carbopol + 3% rutin (CR). The effect of preparations on fibrin glue properties was evaluated by measuring fibrin glue flow time, setting time, pH, and its viscosity. In conclusion, the presence of the studied active substances significantly reduced fibrin glue setting time and, at the same time, had a positive effect on its viscosity, while the formulation containing a higher amount of active substance (CL) turned out to be the most beneficial from the point of view of the prolongation of setting time. The content of both licorice extract and rutin was a positive factor for the pH value of glue, which was more acidic, what probably contributed to improvement in its viscosity. All formulations were found to be more thermo-and enzymatically stable in the presence of the studied additives.

He was found with right sided papilledema, right hearing loss and increased neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture revealed increased levels of protein, opening pressure and cells. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) smears were positive for acid-fast bacilli (Romanowsky stain). The CSF also showed an increase of lymphocytes and the patient had the following blood abnormalities: elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, polymorphism neutrophils in 10% of blood cells, increased C-reactive protein, anemia and reduced thrombocytes. The patient was started on tuberculostatic drugs and antibiotics. Magnetic resonance Imaging (MRI) scanning was performed within the first week of the disease using conventional scanners, without an injection of contrast dye, and revealed hyperintensities on fluid-attenuation compensated (FAC). The second and third scanner were GE scanners. FAC-images obtained on both the GE and the Siemens scanners showed a hyperintense area in the brain parenchyma. # Introduction
Renal anaemia, a complication of chronic kidney disease (CKD), is an important prognostic marker and often leads to anaemia in patients with CKD. Anaemia is associated with increased risk of mortality, vascular complications, fatigue, reduced quality of life and increased risk of hospitalisation [2À4]. Renal anaemia primarily occurs as a consequence of impaired erythropoietin production by the kidneys; this is thought to occur through a number of mechanisms, including reduced bone marrow blood flow, impaired hypoxia and erythropoietin responsiveness, and the effects of inflammation. In an individual with normal iron stores, reduced erythropoietin synthesis is not associated with anaemia [5À7], as other erythropoietin stimulating agent (ESA) classes (i.e. darbepoetin alfa and epoetin) also stimulate erythropoietin production and act in a similar way. However, in patients with CKD, iron deficiency leads to a relative ESA deficiency and increases the risk of mortality . As a consequence, the standard of care in CKD is to treat patients with renal anaemia to a baseline haemoglobin (Hb) concentration of 11 g/dl or higher, using both ESAs and intravenous iron (IV). It should be noted that, in practice, the majority of patients initiated on ESA therapy may not reach a baseline Hb of 11 g/dl either because of insufficient titration or due to intolerance of the side effects, and therefore, in routine practice, some patients may start therapy at a lower Hb threshold.

Numerical study of the electromagnetic properties of tetravalent tungsten clusters.
We report a study of tetravalent tungsten clusters, W4(4-), by means of first principles calculations. The calculated structural and optical and Raman spectra agree well with experimental data. The optical transitions of this molecule are analyzed in terms of a four-orbital model in combination with a ligand field model that includes a distortion term. The observed vibronic bands are interpreted in terms of symmetry-allowed transitions between the states of each localized orbital. The Raman spectrum and the vibration frequencies are in agreement with the reported experimental features. The potential of several vibrational modes, which are characteristic of specific electronic-orbital transitions, is investigated with respect to the optical spectrum of this molecule. Prevalence of Pure and Mixed Hypertension in a Population Sample
We analyzed 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring (ABPM) data to examine the prevalence of pure and mixed hypertension in a large population sample. Over 24 consecutive hours in a random sample (n = 250), we recorded average pressure in office, in bed, and during the day, and the percent time blood pressure exceeded normal levels. From the ABPM data, we identified a sample of 28 subjects with normotensive (NT) 24-hour ABPM patterns while taking antihypertensive medication and a sample of 61 subjects with hypertensive 24-hour ABPM. In these subjects, we identified pure hypertension based on the ABPM and found only 7 of them to be mixed hypertensive. A large proportion of individuals with a diagnosis of hypertension have an NT 24-hour ABPM pattern, but a significant percentage have an abnormal 24-hour ABPM pattern. These data support the use of ABPM in diagnosis and in predicting therapeutic response. The role of PAR2 in epithelial innate immunity: differential regulation of beta-defensins and CCL20 by PAR2 in human colon derived HT-29 cells.
Inflammatory bowel disease is an acquired inflammatory condition involving the gastrointestinal tract. Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic component and results from an interaction between genetic susceptibility and environmental factors. Human-beta defensins (hBDs) and CCL20 (the beta-chemokine CXCL10) are two major genetic contributors to inflammatory bowel disease. Although hBDs and CCL20 are implicated in immunoregulation, their role in inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis is still under investigation. In this study, we demonstrated that epithelial cell-specific protease-activated receptor-2 (PAR2) activation down-regulated expression of defensins and CCL20 in HT-29 colonic epithelial cells. Activation of PAR2 using receptor-specific peptides induced rapid and transient production of interleukin (IL)-8, a cytokine previously shown to be involved in inflammatory bowel disease, supporting the role of PAR2 as a contributor in the initiation and perpetuation of inflammation in inflammatory bowel disease. We used reporter plasmids containing defensin or CCL20 promoter region to demonstrate that PAR2 did not directly regulate defensins and CCL20 through transcriptional regulation, although PAR2 did modulate secretion of the defensins. In conclusion, the epithelial protease cascades regulate the innate immune response by activating epithelial-specific PAR2 receptors. OBJECTIVE
To clarify the prognostic value of the hemodynamic data in children after congenital heart surgery by using early pressure-rate indexes ratio and left ventricular ejection fraction.


METHOD
Forty-seven children 14 years old, weighing 6-70 kg, 37 after repair of congenital heart disease, underwent cardiac and hemodynamic studies 14+/-0.6 (0.5-35) hours after operation. Left ventricular ejection fraction was measured by pulsed Doppler echocardiography. Systolic time intervals were calculated from the carotid hemodynamic waveform.


RESULTS
The left ventricular ejection fraction was high enough to maintain normal cardiac output. Left ventricular ejection fraction showed a moderate correlation with the cardiac index (r=0.4, 0.01>P>0.001). The aortic flow velocity time integral and right atrioventricular conduction time showed a moderate correlation with stroke volume (r=0.36, P<0.05). Systemic vascular resistance index and aortic flow velocity time were not correlated with cardiac index. There was an inverse correlation between systolic time intervals and cardiac index (aortic flow velocity time integral, r=-0.7, P<0.001; right ventricular pre-ejection period, r= -0.76, P<0.001; left ventricular pre-ejection period, r=-0.65, P<0.001). The early pressure-rate index ratio index showed inverse correlations with systemic vascular resistance index (r=-0.71, P<0.001) and right ventricular pre-ejection period (r=-0.58, P<0.001).


CONCLUSION

Eccentric Torque Prediction from EMG Based on Neural Networks

This paper presents a method for predicting eccentric torque from EMG signals using a two-layer neural network. Using the EMG-torque relationship data, the first layer of the neural network is used to establish the relationship between muscle activation (EMG amplitude) and torque in the elbow flexion-extension activity. The second layer is trained to predict the torque by using EMG input signals, which were collected and processed using the first neural network. To train the second neural network, a modified genetic algorithm is used. The EMG and torque data are recorded from six subjects at the elbow flexion-extension activity. The evaluation method of the neural network is based on the Pearson's correlation coefficients. Results show that for the 6 subjects, R-square coefficient of regression line and the prediction correlation coefficient values were 0.994 and 0.997 for elbow flexion, respectively.

Thank you, <OP>, for these suggestions. I will certainly consider them when designing the study. Prevention of hypoxia induced lung damage in rat lipopolysaccharide activated neutrophils.
The lung damage caused by neutrophils activation is a major component of various neutrophilic inflammatory reactions, which can aggravate an existing lung damage. A combination of lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and hypoxia-activated lung inflammation, has been considered as the major cause of acute respiratory distress syndromes (ARDS). Since neutrophils are major players in these reactions, the present study aimed to identify the preventive effects of l-arginine (l-arg), as a precursor of nitric oxide (NO), and of caffeic acid (CA) as an inhibitor of NFkB and a potent antioxidant molecule on the damage of lung tissue of rat caused by neutrophils. A combination of CA with l-arg showed the highest survivability. It seems that the effect of l-arg is mediated via NO while CA may exert its effect through the suppression of NFkB and inflammatory mediator production. The results confirmed the preventive effects of CA and l-arg on lung inflammations in normal and damaged lungs by neutrophills. Thus, treatment with both compounds may improve the outcome of the hypoxia-induced pneumonia. BACKGROUND

The use of recombinant human bone morphogenetic protein-2 (rhBMP-2) as an autograft alternative appears to be a promising option in spine surgery. The clinical potential for this novel agent in the treatment of compression fractures, pseudarthroses, and spinal deformities has been well-documented in human and animal studies. There is an emerging body of literature based on case reports and larger series examining the efficacy of rhBMP-2 in patients with vertebral compression fractures. The use of rhBMP-2 also provides an alternative to autograft bone in cervical deformity cases where anterior cervical fusion is desirable, as well as in patients with severe degenerative lumbar scoliosis who are not candidates for pedicle screw fusion. There is also preliminary evidence that rhBMP-2 may be a suitable adjunct to spinal instrumentation in patients with spinal deformity and to support posterior instrumented fusions in cases of adult spinal deformity. The gut microbiota (GM), a collection of microbial strains, plays a pivotal role in maintaining human health. Recently, it has been increasingly recognized that GM is not only responsible for multiple physiological processes, such as nutrient digestion and absorption, but also participates in the pathogenesis of various diseases, including enteric disorders and central nervous system (CNS) disorders, by mediating the gut-brain axis (GBA). The emerging understanding of GM has led to its increasingly accepted role in the diagnosis and treatment of enteric and CNS disorders. Gut microbiota metabolic end products (GEMs) produced by gastrointestinal microorganisms are regarded as a bridge between gut and host, thus affecting multiple CNS functions. More specifically, GM metabolic products, such as SCFAs, bile acids (BAs), and trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO), modulate host immunity, metabolism and intestinal homeostasis by interacting with the human gut immune system and other systems. Notably, GM metabolites have been widely reported to be involved in the pathophysiological mechanisms of CNS disorders, including autism, anxiety, depression, dementia, and Parkinson's disease. Here, we focus on GM metabolites, including SCFAs, BAs, and TMAO, to elaborate the relationship between GM and CNS disorders and offer novel therapeutic opportunities of GM as CNS disorder therapies, which is of great importance. We also discuss the advantages and disadvantages of targeted therapy focused on GM, in order to promote research of GM and GBA in diseases, especially CNS disorders.

Objective: Recently, mutations in epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) and HER2 have been identified in both tumor cells and plasma of breast cancer patients. However, the potential role of these mutations in saliva remains poorly understood. The aim of this study was to detect mutations in EGFR and HER2 genes in saliva obtained from cancer patients using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and real-time PCR. Methods: Mutational analyses of exons 19 and 21 of the EGFR gene, and of exon 20 of the HER2 gene in saliva by a real-time PCR, the Luminex xMAP suspension bead array. Results: A total of 32 samples were collected from patients with breast cancer patients, and 20 out of 32 samples were positive for salivary mutation. In all, 4 out of 32 cases carried mutations in the EGFR gene in salivary DNA. One of the four patients who harbored EGFR mutations in exon 19 showed a mutation in the plasma and saliva. 9/32 samples revealed HER2 gene mutations in the exon 20. Mutations in the HER2 gene were also found in plasma and saliva for 1 patient who had plasma and salivary EGFR and HER2 gene mutations.

Ipilimumab can cause immune mediated side effects that clinicians are becoming increasingly familiar with. They include cutaneous reactions, colitis, endocrinopathies and hepatic toxicity. We report here a case of ipilimumab induced pancreatitis. It occurred during the second course of treatment in a 66-year-old patient treated for metastatic melanoma in complete response and with stable hepatic metastases. The patient presented with 5 days of vomiting and severe epigastric pain. Clinical examination revealed a severe dehydration and hypokalaemia; initial serum amylase and lipase levels were raised to 250 U and 755 U/ml respectively. Abdominal CT scan and MRI revealed pancreatitis with multifocal areas of necrosis. INTRODUCTION
Currently, resorbable platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) membranes have shown positive results in the treatment of furcal perforations in the primary molars. They seem to support the biological sealing and improve the inflammatory process.


AIM
Investigate the efficacy of endoclasped root canal treatment of canines with the use of two different types of materials for membrane construction: resorbable PRF-fibrin membrane and synthetic collagen membrane for primary molars.


METHODS
The study included 13 cases of endoclasped root canal treatment of canines and the respective control teeth which also underwent endoclasped root canal treatment with a synthetic collagen membrane. The periapical index was determined prior to the procedure and after endoclasped root canal treatment. For the study, periapical radiographs were taken at the follow-up visits made after one year, three years, and five years. The periapical index showed a statistically significant difference between the initial visit and the 5-year visit in both canines (P = 0.0001) and control teeth (P = 0.0001).


MAIN CONCLUSIONS
When comparing the success rate of endoclasped root canal treatment in permanent canines and molars after a follow-up period of more than 10 years, no statistically significant differences were found (P = 0.88), a success rate of 94.9% and 93.2%, respectively.

A reversed phase HPLC coupled with diode array detector method was used, for the first time, to quantify phenolic compounds: chlorogenic acid, epicatechin (EC), catechin (CT), and rutin (Rt) in extracts of leaves and cultivated roots of Eleutherococcus sieboldianus. Chromatographic separation was achieved within 30 min through a normal-phase octadecylsilyl (ODS) column using the gradient elution of acetonitrile and 5 mmol/L potassium phosphate buffer of pH 3.0. The validation of the HPLC procedure for these analytes was carried out by investigating the linearity, precision, accuracy, limit of detection, limit of quantification, and stability, and the data showed that the method is precise and accurate, the calibration curves are linear (r = 0.9997-0.9994) over the range from 8 to 1000 g/mL, and the repeatability relative standard deviations (RSDs) were 0.89-2.44%. The method is suitable for the determination of phenolic compounds in extracts of E. sieboldianus.

Both in vivo and in vitro studies have shown that probiotic microorganisms and their extracellular materials can provide benefits to host cell activity, host cell structure, gut inflammatory responses, intestinal motility, and intestinal permeability. Therefore, probiotics could be used as a method to ameliorate GI dysfunction caused by constipation. Studies have investigated the effects of probiotics using healthy volunteers and demonstrated improved laxation, an increase in intestinal motility, the stimulation of colonic mucus secretion, and an increase in organic acid production. However, these studies had a short follow-up period after the administration of probiotics, and some did not use a control group. Moreover, most studies used non-constipated individuals as the experimental group, and these individuals can be treated as participants of different levels compared to constipated individuals. Therefore, there is still a lack of knowledge regarding the effect of probiotic treatment on constipation, especially in patients with chronic constipation (CC) who have been diagnosed with chronic constipation based on constipation-specific criteria.
It is expected that probiotics and functional foods with probiotic ingredients combined with fecal transplant therapy can be used to treat constipation in the future. Therefore, this study aimed to compare the different effects of four probiotic strains isolated in China as a functional food on GI motility in constipated individuals and non-constipated individuals.
Different mechanisms and benefits to GI motility of individual probiotics would be discussed as well.

Diabetes creates the possibility that an employee may not be able to meet job performance standards, experience accidents or require medical treatment, in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and other federal and state anti-discrimination laws. We conducted a review of the scientific literature on diabetes and work to examine evidence for exclusion from the workplace based on diabetes and its treatments. A literature search using the terms "diabetes and work", "diabetes and job placement" or "diabetes and job qualification" on databases accessed between 2008 and 2011 did not produce any articles on the relationship between type 2 diabetes and the workplace. The National Health Interview Survey, however, did report that 31% of employees who felt it was necessary to be absent from work to take care of a medical problem did so because of diabetes. There appears to be an emerging concern about diabetes and exclusion from the workplace, but a lack of evidence to support it. Despite the lack of concrete evidence, the ADA appears to provide a framework for how to proceed to allow for fair, reasonable accommodations to diabetes in the workplace. .

Major depression is commonly observed before the onset of bipolar disorder. Consequently, a substantial portion of patients with bipolar disorder may be erroneously diagnosed with unipolar depression. The distinction between depression and bipolar disorder is especially important because effective treatment is only available for bipolar disorder. This article reexamines the phenomenology of depression in patients with bipolar disorder and the evidence for a unique clinical profile of bipolar depression using the available information from research articles, reviews, and meta-analyses. A consistent set of findings suggests that depressive symptoms in patients with bipolar disorder (1) are typically worse than unipolar depression and (2) rarely remits without adjunctive mood stabilizers. Moreover, studies in adult and pediatric patients with bipolar depression strongly support the hypothesis that depression is a more severe variant of bipolar disorder. Consequently, depression should be considered a prodromal state of bipolar disorder, and depressed patients who present with clinical pictures intermediate between depression and bipolar disorder deserve thorough and repeated diagnostic evaluations. The disease is highly prevalent in Latin America, parts of Asia and Africa, and, more recently, in eastern Europe and some areas of the United States. Although cerebral calcifications are the result of the organism's degeneration, it's the viable cysts, most of which are found in the basal ganglia, that lead to the devastating clinical sequelae of epilepsy, and cognitive and motor disability. The degree of AKI based on KDIGO classification: (1) No AKI (normal increase in serum creatinine), (2) mild AKI (increase in serum creatinine 1.5-1.9 fold over baseline creatinine), (3) moderate AKI (increase in serum creatinine 2-2.9 fold over baseline creatinine), and (4) severe AKI (increase in serum creatinine !3 fold over baseline creatinine). No one developed end-stage kidney disease (estimated GFR <15 ml/min/1.73 m 2 ). Eight patients required ICU admission (21%). Aims: To determine the occurrence of challenging behaviours and its associations with cerebral palsy (CP) in Chinese children aged 2–12 years in Hong Kong. Method: 35 children with CP were selected from the records of the Special Child Assessment Service of a children's hospital and were assessed by a nurse specialist by means of structured interviews with parents completed by a checklist. Results: 80% of cases showed at least one of the behaviours listed on the checklist. The most frequent challenging behaviours were self-harm, stereotyped behaviour and hyperactivity. Non-verbal mentally retarded, low functioning children showed more challenging behaviours than verbal or high functioning children, and the high functioning groups showed less challenging behaviours compared to the moderately and the low functioning groups. Behaviours of children with mixed CP types were more difficult to manage than those of children with spastic CP. Only 24% of the children were receiving any drug therapy to control their behaviours. Conclusion: The behaviour patterns, which are similar to those reported by other researchers of different cultures, suggest that challenging behaviours are common in children with CP aged 2–12 years in Hong Kong. Further clinical and research studies are needed, especially on long-term prospective studies of CP with special attention to the challenging behaviours and the use of various treatments. OBJECTIVE
To determine the effect of different antigen loading conditions (with heat-killed bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG), freezing and thawing, sonication) on the sensitization of murine RAW264.7 macrophage cell line to rBCG30, a fusion protein composed of a heat-labile enterotoxin from Escherichia coli and the BCG 30-kDa region.


METHOD
Recombinant plasmid pET28alpha-His-rBCG30 was constructed to express the fusion protein rBCG30 in E. coli. rBCG30, native BCG (nBCG) without antigen loading treatment, and heat-killed BCG (hBCG) after antigen loading treatment by freezing, thawing, and sonication were used for the sensitization of RAW264.7 macrophage cell line. The cytotoxicity and proliferation of RAW264.7 cells were then detected by using MTT method.


RESULT
Compared with the other three groups, rBCG30-treated group had the strongest cytotoxicity (2.78-fold) and proliferation ability (10.82-fold) toward RAW264.7 cells. In addition, hBCG-treated (2.29-fold), freeze-thawed nBCG-treated (2.66-fold), and sonicated nBCG-treated (1.96-fold) groups had much stronger cytotoxicity than rBCG30-treated group. The proliferation ability of RAW264.7 cells in rBCG30-treated group was 2.78-fold higher than that in freeze-thawed nBCG-treated group.


CONCLUSION
For RAW264.7 cells, rBCG30 is superior to hBCG, freeze-thawed nBCG, and sonicated nBCG in sensitization to RAW264.7 macrophage cell line. S

Focused Ultrasound Treatment of Breast Cancer-Induced Bone Pain: Report of Three Cases

Breast cancers that metastasize to bone tissue can cause pain that is insensitive to systemic therapies. Focused ultrasound therapy (FUS) aims to disrupt this nociception. We present three cases of FUS of different durations in patients with bone metastasis pain. We find that the duration of follow-up and the number of sonications are not associated with pain reduction in this population. Increasing sonication times was associated with increased analgesics utilization in the acute post-treatment timeframe, however, this may be attributable to patients' underlying bone metastasis pain. Further research is needed to assess the long-term efficacy of FUS and characterize associated outcomes.

Assessment of the effectiveness of a vibrating suture needle

A systematic study of the performance of the vibrating suture needle using two prototypes of the vibrating suture needle (VS_M1 and VS_M2), and reference straight needles, is presented. The VS_M1 needle was made of brass, whereas VS_M2 was made of a stainless steel. In addition, two different suture threads were examined (PDS and Mersilk). Parameters taken into consideration during the study were tensile strength, the breaking load of the suture, knot security as well as knot efficiency. All tests were conducted in liquid and air, employing a Zwick 5595 universal testing machine. The tests were carried out on the samples of tissue taken from pig's skin. All tests were repeated three times. The results were statistically analyzed. The VS_M2 suture was superior to the VS_M1, and PDS was better than Mersilk. In addition, the difference in breaking load between Mersilk and PDS was statistically significant (P ≤ 0.05) in every case, whereas for other parameters their difference was not statistically significant (P > 0.05), but still the trend of the better results in the case of PDS appeared. The analysis of the results allowed the conclusion that the vibratory effect improved the performance of the prototype needle in all cases, both as regards liquid and air tests, as well as tissue samples. The Mersilk threads were also better than PDS in every case.

Comparison of intensive dipyridamole and regadenoson myocardial perfusion imaging with exercise stress testing as a gate-keeper for invasive coronary angiography.
UNLABELLED
There is limited information on comparing dipyridamole and regadenoson myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI) with clinical exercise stress testing (ET) to predict invasive coronary angiography (ICA) findings.


OBJECTIVE
To compare dipyridamole and regadenoson myocardial perfusion imaging to ET as a gate-keeper for invasive coronary angiography.


METHODS
From January 2008 to September 2009, 86 patients with symptoms suggestive of coronary artery disease (CAD) presenting to our outpatient clinic were randomized to undergo resting myocardial perfusion imaging after either regadenoson (44 patients) or dipyridamole (42 patients) and stress myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI) after dipyridamole or regadenoson infusion. SPECT was performed at rest and 35 minutes (MPI) or 1 hour (radionuclide ET) after intravenous vasodilator. Of the 35 patients with a positive result on either resting or stress MPI and/or radionuclide ET, ICA was performed in 28 patients. Invasive coronary angiography (ICA) results were used in combination with the perfusion imaging results for evaluation of the diagnostic accuracy. Results were considered true stress positive if there were at least one 1.5 mm diameter coronary stenosis

Anatomical studies of the submaxillary and hypopharyngeal glands of the hog.
In the course of anatomical studies of the alimentary tract of hogs, attention was called to the presence of large submaxillary or salivary glands (S.A.G.), located in the mucous glandular layer of the internal lining of the buccal cavity, and the hypopharyngeal or pharyngeal glands (H.G.), also occurring beneath the mucous membrane of the upper part of the pharynx. Previously, no mention of such a distribution could be found in the literature. In the following paper, therefore, we give a brief description of the two salivary glands. Their anatomical relations with the neighboring organs will first be briefly discussed. The salivary gland (Figs. 1-4) extends along the bucco-pharyngeal mucous membrane on each side of the floor of the mouth (Fig. 1) extending into the cheek and buccal cavity and into the upper part of the pharynx into the mesopharyngeal region, where it ends, at the boundary of the pharyngeal membrane and the laryngeal membrane. In the mouth the submaxiUary salivary gland extends posteriorly from the anterior margin of the mylohyoid muscle (Figs. 1-2) to the posterior margin of the mylohyoid muscle, and it descends, posteriorly, under the hyoideus superior muscle, to the upper border of the anterior margin of the muscle. With this the gland passes forward, to be included in the mylohyoid muscle. At the most convex part of the curve the anterior end of the gland (submaxillary gland) protrudes into the buccal cavity. The salivary gland runs vertically in the mesopharyngeal mucous membrane toward the pharyngeal membrane in which it terminates. The submaxillary salivary gland runs parallel to the nasopharyngeal membrane and extends from about a half of the breadth of the upper maxilla to the lower border of the hyoideus anterior muscle

Objective: The purpose of this study was to test the salutogenic effects of a brief, mindfulness intervention administered during chemotherapy on patients with advanced cancer. Participants: A convenience sample of 63 patients with advanced cancer (40 men and 23 women) was randomly allocated (56.1% response rate) to a 21-day brief mindfulness intervention (n = 34) or control group (n = 29), which received self-care advice only. Methods: At baseline, 4, 12 and 24 months, participants completed a battery of questionnaires. A repeated measures ANOVA was conducted to examine the effect of the intervention on baseline salutogenic states over time. Results: A significant treatment effect was found, which was mediated by perceived social integration (independent, Δ = 0.36; F = 17.12; 18 degrees of freedom; p = 0.04; h2 = 0.12). Posthoc analysis revealed a significant treatment effect of the intervention on perceived social integration at the 12-month time point (p = 0.004). Conclusion: A brief mindfulness intervention, delivered during chemotherapy, may have a stronger effect on salutogenic states (such as perceived social integration) and a stronger impact on chemotherapy-induced stress via perceived social integration in patients with advanced cancer. A study was made of the effects of epinephrine on coronary blood flow, venous and arterial contents of potassium and lactic acid concentration, and oxygen intake and intake/extraction ratios in 52 closed-chest dogs. In these experiments, epinephrine was administered intravenously over two second durations at rates of 3, 5, and 1000 micrograms/kg per minute (0.7, 1.2, and 20 mg/kg per minute). No significant changes from the initial values of any of the measured variables were noted, at the lowest dose (3 micrograms/kg per minute). At the dose two times this value (5 micrograms/kg per minute), coronary flow at first increased slightly and the concentration of lactic acid in the coronary sinus reached peak concentration of 1 mEq per liter of blood per minute at four minutes following the start of administration of epinephrine. The first measurements of the oxygen intake/extension ratio revealed the lowest value (0.57) at the highest rate of drug administration (1000 micrograms/kg per minute). At both three and five times lower rates of drug administration, the mean figure for this ratio was essentially unchanged (0.78, 0.78). The venous plasma content of lactic acid, the oxygen content of the coronary sinus blood, and the myocardial oxygen consumption were less affected by epinephrine than were the potassium, coronary flow, coronary sinus pressure, or arterial content of lactic acid, The latter variables were, with the highest dose, decreased up to 5.5 mEq per liter after the start of the administration of epinephrine. After this dose had been administered for 30 minutes, the figure for the oxygen content of the coronary sinus blood and the myocardial metabolism had recovered to within 10% of the pre-epinephr

Pharmacokinetic comparison of different brands of levocetirizine after oral administration
Introduction: As a relatively recent oral antihistamine drug, levocetirizine was expected to have the pharmacokinetic characteristics of other antihistamine agents. However, several studies indicated the differences of levocetirizine's pharmacokinetics after different oral administration. In this study, we systematically review the pharmacokinetics of levocetirizine from pharmacokinetic studies of all branded drugs in the past. Methods: We searched the pharmacokinetics of branded levocetirizine through PubMed, and then collected the relative information, including route and formulation, dose, sampling time, and the main pharmacokinetic parameters. We then compared the levocetirizine's pharmacokinetics after single or multiple oral administration. Moreover, the pharmacokinetics of levocetirizine with different dosage regimen and formulation design were compared. Results: The plasma concentration curve of levocetirizine showed the trend of prolonged exposure after 5-day repeated doses. When the drug was combined with food, in terms of exposure, a higher bioavailability was found in the fed state. In addition, the pharmacokinetic parameters of levocetirizine varied after single and multiple administrations. Some formulation showed longer absorption and higher bioavailability, which was related to the enhanced formulation absorption, whereas others showed the changes of absorption rate, Cmax, and AUC, which might be the results of drug and nutrient competition for cell absorption. Conclusion: When administered once daily and to be used chronically, levocetirizine pharmacokinetics need further study and attention, and the therapeutic indications of different formulations should be established at the same time. Objective: To investigate the relationship between preoperative levels of coagulation function and cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea after endoscopic endonasal surgery. Methods: Clinical data of 115 patients with pituitary tumors undergoing endoscopic endonasal surgery in Department of Neurosurgery, Xuanwu Hospital from August 2017 to November 2018 were retrospectively analyzed. These patients were divided into the cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea group (n=19) and the non-cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea group (n=96). The preoperative and postoperative levels of D-dimer and prothrombin time (PT) of the two groups were compared by unpaired t test, and Logistic regression model was used to analyze the risk factors related to cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea. Results: The preoperative levels of D-dimer and PT of the cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea group were higher than those of the non-cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea group (P<0.01). The Logistic regression analysis showed that the preoperative D-dimer and PT of the cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea group were risk factors related to cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea (OR=1.004 and 0.303), and the levels of PT and D-dimer were independent risk factors related to cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea .The area under the ROC curve of preoperative D-dimer and PT levels of cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea-related were 0.833, 0.808, 0.660, and 0.657, respectively. 3-Phosphoinositidedependent kinase 1 (PDK1, alias PKB kinase β) is a member of the 3phosphoinositide-dependent protein kinases (PDK) family.

# Function
PDK1, also known as PKB kinase β, is a protein serine/threonine kinase, belonging to the AGC (PKA/PKG/PKC) kinase family.   The AGC kinases share amino acid sequence homology in the kinase catalytic domain, including the HRD (H342-R348-D349-FDRV) lysine-conserved sequence.
PDK1 is a 62 kDa serine-threonine kinase consisting of a N-terminal PH (pleckstrin homology) domain followed by a PIF (protein kinase A, protein kinase C-binding site) regulatory domain, a catalytic domain, and a PH domain at the very C-terminus. PIF domain of PDK1 binds to phosphoinositides with a higher affinity than the phospholipase C/inositol lipid requiring (PLC-IPH) domain in phospholipase C (PLC).
Activated AGC kinases possess a characteristic feature in their C-terminal regions, an autoinhibitory segment which regulates the kinase activity. This structural feature is found in PDK1, Akt, protein kinase C (PKC), glycogen synthase kinase 3 (GSK-3), protein kinases A and G (PKA and PKG); the autoinhibitory segment is named the molecular switch.
In the absence of activating signals, PDK1 is bound to its substrates in an inactive conformation with the N-terminal PIF domain blocking the kinase domain from binding to its substrate. Binding of PI3K activating

Evolution of the biosynthesis and regulation of fungal melanins
This review discusses the biosynthesis and regulation of fungal melanins. For fungi, melanin pigments have long been recognized for their protective roles. Melanins are the principal cause of sexual mating and mycelium melanization in many basidiomycetes and may also be involved in a wide variety of other functions. The pigments were shown to be composed of two major fractions, DHN‐melanin and brown/black or dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN)‐melanin and 1,8‐dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN)‐melanin, depending on the fungal species. Melanin pigments are synthesized from dihydroxy‐naphthalene and dihydroxynaphthalene precursors in a unique two‐step pathway, which include both enzymatic and non‐enzymatic reactions. These studies on the structure of pigments and the production pathway indicated a simple and universal melanin biosynthesis route in fungi. However, it remains to be established whether this route is also present for fungal melanin in some other fungal species, which contain melanin pigments and their biosynthesis genes. In addition, in recent years, some new pigmentation compounds have been identified in some fungal species. The synthesis and regulation of melanin and these new pigments have been mainly investigated by analysis of fungal gene expression. However, the genetic mechanisms that govern the biosynthesis of these pigments are not well understood, and further studies are needed to fill this gap. Background: Chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) is a common disorder that affects approximately 14-16 % of the Western population, with 2-5% of these having recalcitrant cases. It is difficult to pinpoint the reason behind the persistence of CRS in a patient. One factor that may influence the development of CRS is the overuse or misuse of antibiotics. Objectives: To determine the prevalence and variation in bacterial sensitivity to common antibiotics in CRS patients and compare them to controls. Materials and Methods: We extracted the middle meatus mucus from CRS and controls patients and tested it for three different antibiotics using two methods (disk-diffusion and minimum inhibitory concentration [MIC]). Results: The MIC method had 92% correlation with results determined using the disk-diffusion method. The MIC of amphotericin B was significantly greater in the CRS group in contrast to the control group. The CRS group demonstrated a significantly higher MIC for penicillin. Conclusion: Our study findings suggest that the CRS and controls groups have statistically significant differences based upon their resistance to amphotericin B, penicillin, and doxycycline and based upon their sensitivity to cefuroxime. Amphotericin B and penicillin were the two antibiotics that varied the most between the CRS group and controls and may be worthy of investigation. We conclude that overuse of antibiotics may result in a higher level of antimicrobial resistance in CRS patients, hence this may contribute to the development of CRS.

Purpose: In this study, we evaluated thyroid gland phantoms used as the learning tool in thyroid fine-needle aspiration (FNA), the primary diagnostic test for thyroid nodules. Methods: We developed a thyroid gland phantom using gelatin and commercial thyroid tissue samples. The phantom included a lymph node model, simulating 18 FDG PET/CT findings of a thyroid cancer metastasis. The phantom was designed for US-guided FNA and included four tissue structures representing four thyroid nodules, three of them containing a metastatic lymph node. Thyroid gland phantoms were imaged using a 3.0-T PET/MRI with PET, MRI, real-time ultrasound, and hybrid PET/US. Results: The phantoms were evaluated by six radiologists who were provided the images and asked to perform FNA on the phantom. The mean accuracy was 97.56%, with 212 (84.82%) of 248 aspirations performed correctly. The accuracy of metastasis identification was 100% by PET, MRI, and PET/MR images. Conclusion: The phantom provides a tool for teaching FNA. The phantom was acceptable and well evaluated by radiologists.

Escherichia coli O113 is a major porcine pathogen in Norway

In Norway, antimicrobial resistance in Escherichia coli from pigs increases from year to year and many isolates are classified as multidrug-resistant (MDR) or extensively drug-resistant (XDR). The objective of the current study was to investigate the population structure of E. coli isolates recovered from disease outbreaks in pig farms in different Norwegian counties between 2005 and 2013. In total, 4643 isolates characterised by biochemical tests and enterobacterial repetitive intergenic consensus-PCR were typed by serotyping, phage typing and multilocus sequence typing (MLST). A total of 298 isolates were analysed by pulsed-field gel electrophoresis and whole-genome sequencing. All isolates carried both the adhesion factor fimH allele A (a major factor in virulence) and the adhesin gene papA. Among the isolates, serogroup O113 was dominant (n = 1234). Serotype O113:K89 was the most frequent (424/424) with a second O113 serotype O8:K71 (400/424). Phage typing showed both an O113-and O8-typing, whereas PCR detection of genomic islands, pathogenicity islands and virulence genes did not show differences between serotypes. This indicates that the O113 isolates carry a common resistance plasmid genome. The serotype O8:K71, phage group B2 isolates only formed a small cluster by MLST and pulsed-field gel electrophoresis. Oryza rhizophila (J. R. Molas), a new indigenous Thai strain of filamentous ascomycetes, is reported in this work to be a good source of an extracellular enzyme, namely α‐amylase, which is currently of interest to the starch industry. The enzyme was produced and characterized. To the best of our knowledge this is the first such report on a newly characterized fungal strain isolated from northeast Thailand which produces an extracellular α‐amylase. The α‐amylase produced by the strain was detected in the culture filtrate of fungus grown in glucose‐containing liquid culture at 28°C for 7 days. The enzyme was purified to homogeneity by sequential column chromatography. The purified enzyme showed a single protein band with a molecular weight of 32 kDa in both SDS‐PAGE and zymographic analysis. The activity was determined by both spectrophotometric and titration methods and was maximal between pH 5 and 6 and at 45°C. The Km and Vmax were determined to be 1.21 mM and 13.3 unit/min, respectively. In addition, we investigated the ability to use starch syrup as a substrate and the role of this enzyme in the saccharification of the starch. The enzyme hydrolyzed starch at hydrolysis, giving maltose as a main disaccharide product with a minor amount of glucose formed. Thus, the purified enzyme has a potential for the release for maltose of native starch. However, in the saccharification of starch, the results are not consistent with the role of the α‐amylase in the breakdown of starches to release maltose. Rickettsia Species Diversity of Ants in the Mediterranean Region: Incomplete Molecular Characterization Raises Concerns About Underestimating Rickettsia Presence in Ants
ABSTRACT: Rickettsia spp. are obligate symbionts present in many arthropod species, including ticks and fleas. We investigated the prevalence and diversity of Rickettsia spp. in Mediterranean ants collected from France and Egypt from 2015 to 2019. We used PCR primers to amplify the gltA gene of the bacteria, and Sanger sequencing and bioinformatics were used to characterize Rickettsia species. We recovered 200 partial gltA sequences, 83% of which (167 sequences) were identified as Rickettsia. Rickettsia-positive ants were found in 4 out of the 5 years in France, 2 seasons (summer and autumn) in Egypt, and 5 ant species (Myrmecia nigrocincta (F. Smith), Pheidole hartmanni (Forel), Cataglyphis duloticus (Roger), Pheidole fallax (F. Smith), and Odontomachus montanus (Roger) (Hymenoptera: Formicidae). The sequences identified 18 different gltA types in France, whereas two sequences of the same gltA type were found in France and in two individuals from Egypt. In contrast, two different gltA types were found in Egypt (one in a Ph. duloticus and another in a Od. montanus). The results of this study demonstrate the diversity of Rickettsia spp. in ants collected from diverse collection sites and the occurrence of two Rickettsia gltA types, one in France and one in Egypt, in phylogenetically related taxa collected 7,000 km apart. Results of the German and Austrian Liver Transplant Registries.
OBJECTIVE
Qualify of life, function, and survival of 212 adults (169 males and 43 females, mean age 43.1 +/- 8.4 years) transplanted in Germany and Austria between January 1, 1992 and December 31, 1993.


METHOD
Self-evaluation survey using the generic core questionnaire of the "European Organ Transplant Group". Information on demographic characteristics and disease characteristics at the time of transplantation was derived from the German and Austrian Liver Transplant Registry data base.


RESULTS
Mean duration of hospital-stay after transplantation was 29.1 +/- 19.1 days. 18 (1-42) of 212 patients died during the first year. In the 1-year follow-up period, 125 (59.0%) patients participated in the survey. All patients surviving the first postoperative year showed satisfactory medical, psychological, and social results. Surviving patients reported a better QOL in all dimensions than liver-transplanted patients who died. A strong predictor of patients survivorship was the extent of the acute rejection episode in the 3-month post-Tx period. The overall improvement of liver-failure symptoms was accompanied by a marked improvement of muscle tone and strength.


CONCLUSION
In the first post-Tx year, adult patients showed considerable improvement of QOL, physical, and psychosocial health status. The development of a national and international data base for liver transplant patients will permit a prospective and systematic analysis of posttransplant outcome factors. Purpose of Review
Population groups that identify as transgender or gender nonconforming (GNC) and/or have gender diversity in their sexual orientations (ie, bisexual individuals, gay men, lesbian women, queer people, or gender nonbinary people) are increasingly important to understand in relation to global HIV prevention and treatment. This review describes the prevalence of these populations worldwide and highlights evidence for the influence of minority stress on HIV risk in this population.


Recent Findings
We searched online databases including PubMed using the terms (transgender* or transsexual* or nonbinary* or gender-nonconforming*) and HIV OR AIDS OR ARV OR PrEP OR TasP OR (anti-)retroviral* OR ARV OR PrEP OR TasP OR (anti-)retroviral* using combinations of title, abstract and Medical Subject Headings for the last 12 years.


Summary
The minority stress model is often used to explain HIV risk and disparities, and it has been applied to studies in some regions investigating sociodemographic differences in risk or health status. There is a dearth of studies looking at minority stress theory applied to individuals who identify as gender-nonconforming or sexual minorities, however, the minority stress model may help illuminate the potential pathways to HIV risk in these populations. Thus, understanding how minority stress models may influence global HIV risk in this population requires further study, including consideration of the specific mechanisms by which sexual risk may be mediated in this population.

# Introduction
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) consists of a heterogeneous group of diseases that have very different prognostic outcomes. Although chemotherapy is the gold standard for AML treatment, it is often ineffective and does not prolong progression of the disease 1 .
One of the novel treatments for AML, inotuzumab ozogamicin (BEAT AML), is an anti-CD22 monoclonal antibody and antineoplastic agent that has demonstrated favorable clinical results in various types of AML 2 . The agent links to the active metabolite calicheamicin, a topoisomerase I-inhibiting compound that cleaves DNA in proximity to the mAb, thereby acting as a mechanism-based linker drug 2 . Inotuzumab ozogamicin has the potential to treat refractory/relapsed AML, as well as CD22-positive AML 2 .
CDKN2A, IKZF1, NPM1, NRAS, RUNX1, and TET1 are the most common AML-associated genetic mutations and have prognostic relevance. FMS-related receptor tyrosine kinase 3 (FLT3) has a mutation that has prognostic relevance in the FLT3-internal tandem duplication subgroup. For example, for cytogenomic AML, prognostic relevance is observed when karyotypic abnormalities are seen with other gene mutations in NPM1 or FLT3 mutations, or for the chromosome 5 or chromosome 7 alterations   Cytogenetics in acute myeloid leukemia, Anwer  . AIM: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) has been extensively studied in terms of vascular development, including angiogenesis, permeability, vasculogenesis and vascular development during embryogenesis. The TM4 cell line was derived from the yolk sacs of transgenic mice harbouring the simian virus 40 large T antigen under the control of a promoter from the thymidine kinase gene from S-12 adenovirus. BACKGROUND AND AIMS
Annonaceae is a species-rich tropical plant family. However, taxonomic relationships among its subfamilies have been contentious. The main objective is to evaluate the taxonomic relationships in Annonaceae using molecular evidence.


METHODS
Three chloroplast genomic regions, trnL-trnG, trnH-psbA and psbA-trnK, and the ITS region of the nuclear ribosomal genes of Annonaceae were sequenced. Phylogenetic analyses (ML and MP) of the resulting datasets were performed to resolve the phylogenetic relationships. Supports for clades were evaluated using 100,000 bootstrap replicates.


KEY RESULTS
Bayesian and maximum parsimony phylogenetic analyses indicate that Annonaceae comprises three subfamilies: Malmeoideae, Guatterioideae and Annoneae with 100 % bootstrap support for each. The Malmeoideae are paraphyletic, but comprise the Anaxagoreoideae, the Malmeeae and the Pseuduvarieae, which are supported at 100 % bootstrap for each.


CONCLUSIONS
In addition, the phylogenetic positions of several genera have been modified: Annickia and Chrysophyllum have been placed in the Guatterioideae; Alphonsea, Annona, Bocagea, Calycomnicum, Erepsacalles, Lophostigma, Markhamia, Milianda and Perennandra, in the Malmeoideae; and Amoora in the Annoneae. The genera Acevoa, Aphaneranthera, Colubrina, Conchopetalum, Cryptocarya, Klainedoxa, Pellodendron, Pseuduvaria, Parrya, Preissia and Uvaria in the Annoneae are placed in the Malmeoideae.

Since 1978 we have carried out a program to survey dental caries in 12-year old children since 1978. At present, we continue this program with cooperation of local government which is called the program for oral health management. The aim of this program is to make every child healthy and to support them to have good oral health. Each local official sends out questionnaires to all the children in his jurisdiction before the survey. At that point they are asked if any kind of dental treatment was performed last year. The questionnaire for each child is sent back to us and we make a data base of the data which we get from the answers. We make an oral health check-up for all children who have not received any dental treatment in the previous year all over the country. The children who have not been examined in the previous year are about 15% of all the children in the country. They come to our mobile dental clinics which are set up in each local government for two days. At the oral health check-up, the children have their teeth cleaned and they are given dietary guidance and oral care instruction. In those clinics, the children take oral examination. We have 4 kindsoffor teachers in each local government to help us and work as the public health dentist. We give each teacher a training course to work as a public health dentist before going to the oral check-up clinic. These teachers are the teachers of the local schools who have been given the training course in the 2-day oral health check-up clinics. Nitration sites in human serum albumin and their roles in thrombus formation and thrombus resolution on human vascular surfaces

Protein nitration is emerging as an important post-translational modification of proteins in both physiological and pathological conditions; yet the effects of nitrated albumin on thrombogenicity and thrombus resolution remain unclear. We determined the effect of nitration on the function of human serum albumin (HSA) and human vascular surfaces by using surface plasmon resonance and a custom microfluidics device on the basis of our previous study. We found that nitration of HSA significantly enhanced the binding of thrombin compared with non-nitrated HSA. The functional significance was further supported by the finding that nitrated HSA formed stable adhesion complexes with endothelial cells (ECs), whereas non-nitrated HSA did not. Moreover, nitrated HSA promoted platelet adhesion more potently than did non-nitrated HSA. These in vitro findings suggest that nitration sites contribute to HSA-mediated thrombus formation and thrombus resolution on vascular surfaces. The in vivo relevance of these findings was supported by the result that mice with atherosclerosis treated with nitrated HSA exhibited higher plaque burden than those treated with non-nitrated serum albumin. Taken together, these results suggest that nitration of HSA may contribute to both thrombus formation and thrombus resolution in atherosclerosis.

Ascariasis is caused by infection with Ascaris lumbricoides, a large roundworm infecting millions of people worldwide. While most infections are asymptomatic, they can result in dysenteric diarrhea, abdominal pain, anorexia and weight loss. A major issue in clinical studies of ascariasis is that infection can induce an inflammatory response leading to interference with the efficacy of investigational drugs. We show that in individuals who were not infected with Ascaris, co-treatment with DEC (5 mg/kg per day for 10 days) and dexamethasone (0.3 mg/kg per day for 5 days), reduced the inflammation response caused by intramuscular injection with a mixture of egg antigens (EM) and excretory-secretory products (ES) from Ascaris suum. DEC, but not dexamethasone, significantly reduced egg excretion from the faeces after administration of A. suum-derived ES to participants already infected with A. suum. Co-treatment of individuals with ascariasis and DEC plus dexamethasone, reduced excretion of egg mass by almost half. Additionally, the excretion of immature larvae was similar in participants who received only ES and DEC plus dexamethasone compared with participants who only received ES, suggesting that dexamethasone may reduce immature larvae invasion of the intestine and subsequent maturation to gravid worms. Our observations demonstrate that co-encapsulation of DEC and dexamethasone in a sustained release microsphere formulation could improve the anti-inflammatory effect of DEC and hence the safety of DEC, as well as improve the efficacy of DEC in the treatment of intestinal nematoses. A Dual-Sensor Patch for Continuous Monitoring of Vital Signs
Advanced signal processing combined with wearable sensory systems plays an important role in modern personalized health monitoring. In this work, we present the design, implementation, and evaluation of a fully integrated, flexible dual-sensor wearable patch for the continuous monitoring of electrocardiograms (ECGs) and electrodermal responses (EDRs). The patch is an extension of a previously reported work aimed at continuous respiratory monitoring. The fabrication process consists of a three-step procedure involving the formation of a microfluidic channel to transport sweat through the conductive network of the patch, transferring the integrated circuits and electrodes onto an adhesive substrate, and finally securing the patch onto a flexible backing layer. The system has a high signal-to-noise ratio of 35.6 ± 3 dB and is capable of detecting different states of human stress under controlled psychological stress, providing reliable and useful EDR and RSP measurements for continuous health monitoring applications. .

In Vivo Optical Monitoring of Reactive Oxygen Species in the Mouse Kidney by Using 1064 nm Diffuse Light
Efficient reactive oxygen species (ROS) production by renal tubules and its direct effect on renal tubule cells are well‐known. Renal oxidative stress has been implicated in the progression of acute renal failure and chronic nephropathies. Therefore, noninvasive optical monitoring of ROS in vivo will aid in understanding the role of oxidative stress in experimental models of disease and might enable quantitative real‐time imaging of ROS in humans. This article presents the in vivo quantification of Renilla‐green fluorescent protein as an optical marker of ROS production in the mouse kidney (n = 9 animals). In anesthetized mice, Renilla‐green fluorescent protein‐transfected mouse renal tubules were excited with a 1064 nm diode laser pulse train, and the emitted diffuse light is collected with a 20 mm‐diameter lens. After laser excitation of the fluorescent protein, a photoprotection step was applied to reduce the intensity of light emission. Renilla‐green fluorescent protein‐transfected tubules emit a fluorescent flash every ∼0.08 s. The mean of the peak intensity in 54 flashes was recorded and used as the measure of oxidative stress in 16 min after the first laser pulse. ROS production in the kidney was significantly increased in all animals after an intravenous injection of 25 mg/kg lipopolysaccharide (LPS) (n = 5), a stimulator of the immune system. An Unusual Case of Mucormycosis of the Parotid Gland in HIV Infection

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection commonly seen in immunocompromised hosts. We describe a case of angioinvasive fungal infection of the parotid gland in a 52-year-old HIV-positive patient, caused by the fungus Rhizopus oryzae, and discuss the literature relating to these infections of the parotid gland. Our case highlights the importance of awareness and timely diagnosis of this unusual mucormycosis entity, a condition which may pose diagnostic difficulties due to its unpredictable clinical course.
Introduction. Mucormycosis is an unusual opportunistic fungal infection, increasingly encountered in immunocompromised patients suffering from a compromised mucocutaneous barrier, as in diabetics or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. In HIV-positive patients, mucormycosis commonly occurs in the central nervous system and sinuses. Fungal infections of the salivary glands are rare, with only a few cases of fungal infections of the parotid gland reported in the literature. We describe a case of mucormycosis of the parotid gland in an HIV-positive patient and discuss the relevant literature.

The influence of different oxygenation levels on human blood flow in the upper lip

Background: Improvement of the aesthetic results of dental prostheses depends on an adequate blood supply to the tissues; both blood flow and biorheology have been shown to be influenced by oxygenation.Objectives: This study aimed to evaluate the effect of hyperoxygenation on human blood flow in the upper lip.Materials and Methods: Twenty healthy dental students participated in the study. The test subject was subjected to hyperoxygenation by exhaling into a breathing mask using oxygen from a cylinder (21% O 2 , 79% N 2 ). After a 5-minute oxygenation period, the blood flow was determined in two separate regions of interest (ROI) and the values obtained during normoxia were compared with those obtained in hyperoxygenation by means of ultrasound speckle tracking.Results: During hyperoxygenation, there was a significant increase in blood flow, especially in the areas under the upper lip mucosa that are most frequently affected by vascular pathologies; mean blood flow velocities increased by 64% and 26% in the first and second ROIs, respectively.Conclusion: Hyperoxygenation was associated with an increase in the blood flow in two regions of interest in the upper lip of healthy subjects.

High-performance liquid chromatography/electrospray mass spectrometric methods for qualitative and quantitative analysis of flavonoids in Sophora japonica L.
INTRODUCTION
Despite the widespread traditional usage of Sophora japonica L. (Leguminosae) as a hepatic-protective and antiinflammatory medicinal herb, the chemistry of the medicinal action is poorly elucidated.


OBJECTIVE
In the present study, a high-performance liquid chromatography/electrospray mass spectrometric analytical method was established for quantitative and qualitative analyses of flavonoids in S. japonica.


METHODOLOGY
Chemical extracts from nine S. japonica batches from different regions were chromatographed using a Gemini C(18) column (150 · 4.6 mm, 4 μm) at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The mobile phase was a linear gradient composed of 0.2% formic acid in water (A) and methanol (B), starting with 10% B for 5 min, increasing to 30% B from 6 to 14 min, from 30% B to 50% B from 14.1 to 23 min, and then holding at 50% B for 5 min. The column effluent was introduced into an esquire ion trap mass spectrometer. The mass spectrometer was operated in full-scan multiple-ion detection or multiple-ion monitoring mode.


RESULTS
A total of sixteen flavonoids were identified or tentatively characterised. Three of these compounds, including a rare flavone C-glucoside, were quantified by external standard methods with their calibration curves constructed.


CONCLUSION

This project aims to explore how individuals with idiopathic scoliosis, who have contracted COVID-19, view their health in comparison with individuals with idiopathic scoliosis who have not contracted COVID-19.
For individuals with idiopathic scoliosis, the health implications of the COVID-19 pandemic continue to grow. Researching how those with idiopathic scoliosis perceive and manage health through the experience of the COVID-19 pandemic will serve as the basis for implementing health promotion and disease prevention strategies. As such, the purpose of this study is to understand the experiences of individuals with idiopathic scoliosis, with and without COVID-19, to evaluate how a pandemic such as COVID-19 may impact the experiences of individuals with idiopathic scoliosis. This study employed a mixed methods cross-sectional survey approach to explore this research question with individuals with idiopathic scoliosis. The inclusion criteria included individuals (18 years or older) with idiopathic scoliosis who were diagnosed by a physician or physiotherapist using the relevant radiological test images and/or medical reports, who contracted COVID-19 (verified by the relevant test images and/or medical reports), who received care in Canada, and who did not experience any other health conditions, such as a heart problem or asthma, which may have contributed to a severe case of COVID-19.

The interleukin-1 (IL-1)-induced IRAK-1 serine/threonine kinase is a key regulator of the IL-1-induced IL-1 receptor (IL-1R)-dependent transcriptional responses. This report delineates the role of the IL-1R in forming a large IL-1R cytoplasmic complex composed of IRAK-1 and the IL-1R TRAF adapters, TRAF 2 and TRAF 6, and IL-1R-associated kinase 1 (IRAK‑1). The interaction between IRAK‑1 and TRAF 6 in the absence of IL-1 was very weak. However, in the presence of IL-1, the association between IRAK‑1 and TRAF 6 was substantially increased. Formation of this multicomponent complex required functional IL-1R IL-1R/toll receptor domain. Inhibition of IRAK-1 or IL-1R kinase activity attenuated the recruitment of TRAF 6 to the IL-1R complex. In addition, the interaction of TRAF 6 with IRAK‑1 promoted the IL-1-induced phosphorylation and activation of IRAK-1. The Effect of Aging on Neutrophil Proteome Levels and Functional Activity in Rats

The inflammatory response is characterized by enhanced adhesive properties of neutrophils, thereby affecting cell migration and extravasation at the site of the infectious process. The aim of this study was to examine for the first-time changes in the proteome profile of neutrophils occurring during the senescence process. To our knowledge, this is a new approach to the assessment of aging-related alterations in neutrophil protein concentration. The study was performed on male Wistar rats. Protein concentration in blood serum was examined using a microcolorimetric method. The amount of protein in cell lysates was determined using a commercial kit. Fluorometric assays were used to determine superoxide dismutase activity, glutathione peroxidase activity, and total antioxidant capacity. Western blot analysis was performed to measure the protein concentration of ICAM-1, CD18, and actin in the plasma membrane fraction of neutrophils. The study showed no changes in protein concentration in serum and neutrophils lysates, as well as in the amount of actin. The concentration of ICAM-1 proteins reduced during aging while the level of CD18 proteins increased simultaneously. Total antioxidant capacity, SOD activity, and GPOX activity increased as a result of aging. Our results show for the first time that aging-mediated changes may affect ICAM-1 and CD18 protein levels in cell membranes. In addition, the data suggest that neutrophils are involved in oxidative stress during aging. In this context, an altered protein profile may help to explain the age-related functional disturbances in neutrophils.

HYPOTHESIS
Pro-inflammatory serum cytokines and adipokines were identified as candidate biomarkers to detect sepsis and predict mortality in a sepsis cohort of 902 patients.


DESIGN
Retrospective analysis.


PATIENTS
Consecutive study population of 902 ICU patients with suspected septic shock without a history of sepsis.


METHODOLOGY
Serum concentrations of TNF-alpha, IL-6, IL-10, IL-8, IL-1ra, leptin, adiponectin, resistin, PAI-1, CRP, CK, GGTP, sTNFRI, sTNFRII and sCD14 were measured upon inclusion into the study. The association of each cytokines and biomarker with sepsis and 28-day mortality was studied by logistic regression.


RESULTS
Sepsis-patients had significantly higher levels of all investigated biomarkers than patients without sepsis. Multivariate regression analysis identified sIL-6R, CRP, IL-10, sTNFR1, sCD14 and sTNFRII as significant predictors of sepsis, whereas sIL-6R, IL-8, sTNFR1 and sTNFRII were independent predictors of mortality.


CONCLUSION
We identified specific serum markers for the detection of sepsis and prediction of mortality. These markers may be used at the bedside to detect sepsis in critically ill patients, as they could improve both the diagnostic and the clinical process of sepsis by allowing the timely implementation of therapeutic measures to avoid further negative consequences of septic complications. # Discussion
The discussions section is used to explain and justify the selection of the 26 participants.
The discussions section also illustrates a typical example of how an N of 1 trial protocol can deviate from conventional RCT protocols. One common approach in conventional RCTs is to include a larger sample size than suggested by the statistical power analysis, for example, 20 participants in each group, so that some patients may be included in the study simply because they are available. This is not compatible with an N of 1 approach. Instead we must find as many participants as possible who are both eligible for the investigational treatment and agree to participate in the entire trial period (including the washout). The inclusion period is prolonged to allow enough time to recruit the entire target group of participants. The washout period is also extended to the same duration as the inclusion period. There is no reason to end the inclusion period prematurely because we need a full data set for each patient.
As in most N of 1 studies, there will be cases where it is difficult to find a target participant. For example, if the trial involves 100 patients and one of the participants drops out or withdraws at t 99 , the statistical power of the study will suddenly fall to 0.49. If the study involves 100 patients and a single one of them is recruited first (e.g., a highly motivated patient or one who is willing to receive the investigational treatment), the statistical power will suddenly rise to 1.0. Therefore, if we aim for statistical power of 0.8, we are most likely to find a recruit only for the 1st participant.
N of 1 protocols usually have smaller sample sizes due to the smaller target population size. This means that the results are more likely to be less generalizable. If we, however, need data that is relevant to a specific patient (due to the variation in drug response that is observed), then it may sometimes be better to use a smaller trial sample. In this case, an advantage of an N of 1 trial design is that it

The effect of inhalational induction agents on patients undergoing minor maxillectomy

Background: Inhalational agents are commonly used for airway management and securing surgical conditions. However, patients may undergo various psychological responses to these agents. This retrospective cohort study evaluated whether the type of inhalational agents used during induction of general anesthesia had any effects on patients' reactions and outcomes in patients undergoing minor maxillectomy. Methods: Patients who underwent minor maxillectomy at a tertiary care university hospital in Korea between June 2006 and January 2018 were assigned to either the inhalational propofol agent group (191 eyes) or the inhalational sevoflurane agent group (264 eyes). Data on their preoperative visual analog scores (VAS scores), the type of inhalational agent, and intraoperative surgical conditions were collected from medical records. Results: The mean intraoperative VAS scores in patients in the propofol and sevoflurane groups were 1.79 ± 1.43 and 1.03 ± 0.82, respectively (p = 0.001). The types of inhalational agents used were propofol in 177 eyes (32.1%) and sevoflurane in 338 eyes (57.9%). Intravenous rocuronium was used to secure surgical conditions in most patients in both groups. None of the patients showed evidence of reactive hypoxia or malignant ventricular rhythm, regardless of the type of inhalational agent used. There was no statistically significant intergroup difference in surgical conditions. Conclusion: The types of inhalational agent used in patients who underwent minor maxillectomy did not have any impacts on blood oxygenation, patients' physiological reactions, or intra-operative surgical conditions.

Inclusion and exclusion criteria

The key inclusion and exclusion criteria for the trial, where appropriate, should be clearly stated in either the eligibility criteria or text near the end of the study summary or in the eligibility criteria.
The key inclusion and exclusion criteria should be presented in the recruitment materials to ensure that patients who are approached understand what is required of them if they agree to enrol.

- Key inclusion and exclusion criteria

A key inclusion criterion is a requirement that all potential participants must meet to enrol in the trial. A key exclusion criterion is a requirement that a potential participant would not be eligible to enrol in the trial, even if they met other critical eligibility criteria. Both key inclusion and exclusion criteria should be presented in the recruitment materials.

Some common inclusion criteria include:

  1. Provision of written informed consent
  2. Able to comply with the study protocol
  3. Meets major eligibility requirements, such as inclusion criteria, age, gender, or disease state
  • Some common exclusion criteria include:
    1. Allergy to ingredients in the investigational treatment or study materials
    2. Unwilling or unable to take the investigational treatment or study materials, which may include the study drug, placebo, or other study supplies
    3. Inability to participate in the safety follow-up procedures, such as visit frequency and testing requirements

    Recommendations

Air embolism occurring during endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography is a very rare complication, and most events of air embolism occur perioperatively, intraoperatively, or postoperatively. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography, in general, is a very safe and minimally invasive procedure, and the adverse events are usually mild, transient, and self-limiting. A 55-year-old man underwent endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography because of common bile duct stones. The procedure was uneventful until the stone removal phase, and the procedure was stopped because of severe arrythmia. Shortly after the procedure, cardiac arrest developed and irreversible cardiac arrest occurred and the patient died. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography-related severe complications, such as air embolism, are fortunately rare, although they are sometimes fatal. Clinicians should be aware of complications related to endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography, especially rare but fatal ones, while performing the procedure. ABSTRACT Background: A structured discharge summary (SDS) improves communication between healthcare professionals. However, standard SDSs are difficult to use. Purpose: To quantify documentation errors in SDSs from a cohort of surgeons, and assess the impact of a simple structured SDS (SSDS). Methods/Methodology: The study was conducted in two phases. Phase 1 (N = 43) assessed documentation accuracy of the SDS: documentation errors (DEs) recorded (N = 566 errors); percentages of individual medical staff with 20% or more DEs, and medical staff with >3 errors. Phase 2 (N = 46) compared documentation accuracy of an SSDS with the SDS. Results: Phase 1 SDSs contained 82% more information than SDSs (p < .001) and, despite a 9.5% increase in word count, were 30% quicker to write (p < .001). 41 (49%) SDSs contained >3 (30 ± 9 total errors) and 31 (72%) had >20% DEs (50 ± 6 DEs); staff were equally likely to commit >3 errors as to be accurate in all areas. Errors were most common in: diagnosis (56%; 337/600), postoperative complications (34%; 139/418), and investigation orders (32%; 97/301) (p < .001). An integrated model for the genetic analysis of cancer pathogenesis.
An integrated model that can be used for the genetic analysis of cancer pathogenesis is being developed. It is based on the idea of an interrelated hierarchy of genetic mechanisms. The upper level of the integrated model consists of mechanisms that generate a variety of mutations through various types of errors in DNA replication and DNA repair. These mechanisms are based on the results of many research laboratories that have studied a number of chemical processes involving DNA (alkylation/alkyltransferase, oxidation/antioxidants, O6-alkylguanine DNA alkyltransferase deficiency, etc). Each level, with its associated mechanisms and mutations, is characterized by a set of measurable parameters. These include parameters associated with the individual cells comprising a given organ or tissue, the parameters associated with the organ or tissue, and the parameters associated with the organism. The mechanism and parameters characterizing lower levels of the hierarchy provide quantitative and predictive frameworks for understanding the results of studies involving the other levels. This approach should also contribute significantly to our understanding of the complex pathogenesis of cancer, as well as the complex processes that occur during normal cellular proliferation.
