Mental Disorders on Twitter?
The world wide web has significantly changed people's ways of communication, especially in countries like India, where we have access to fast internet in rural areas too. In this paper, we analyze Twitter usage to understand the way people talk about mental disorders. We have found out that people are actually using Twitter for discussing mental disorders, and the terms used for these include "schizophrenia", "depression", "bpd", "autism", to name a few. A preliminary analysis of the textual patterns of tweets reveals that the content is mainly concentrated in one or two hashtags, while the majority of the hashtags have fewer than 150 tweets. While some hashtags have a large number of tweets, like #ptsd, it does not mean that this hashtag is always used by the same set of users. When we analyze the user profile pages, we notice that a majority of the users' profiles have some links that mention "health" or "mental illnesses", indicating an interest in this topic. The analysis of hashtags shows that there is no hashtag that is purely dedicated to mental disorders, and they are being mixed up with other categories from the mental health and wellness domain. We also notice many "retweets", which means that most of the content that is present on Twitter on this topic is not original content. We analyzed some of the users using an online profiling tool and found 74 users who are also connected to other social media such as Facebook, LinkedIn and Myspace. These profiles were checked individually to determine the profile type, the content in each of the profile pages and the use of profile pages. We noticed that many individuals on Twitter use profile pages as links to their real social networks. This leads to the question whether this data is valuable enough to be analyzed scientifically, with the number of posts that are not original, and the use of the profiles for advertisements being the most concerning aspect of this data. Synthetic genes have been designed and synthesized to encode amino acid sequences that can be cross-linked in vitro to form stable covalent cross-linked protein-based polymer (CPP) networks. In this study, we have selected five random sequences within this cross-linking region and computed their phase behavior with both coarse-grained (discrete molecular dynamics, molecular dynamics) and all-atom (molecular dynamics, metadynamics) simulations. The metadynamics runs allow one to evaluate the free energy landscapes involved, thus enhancing molecular interpretations of experimental results. The molecular simulations of the amino acid sequences show three main thermodynamic phases, including a solid phase, a liquid crystalline phase, and a liquid-crystalline-disordered phase coexistence. We then discuss how these phase behaviors may be used in vivo to improve the properties of cellular compartments. In addition, we provide possible explanations for the lack of information that can be extracted from NMR spectra and atomic force microscopies. Overall, this work gives a better comprehension of the molecular properties of this class of materials and gives insight toward their biomedical applications. BACKGROUND
Leprosy is an endemic skin and peripheral nerve disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae (M. leprae). Globally, 120 countries have been identified as endemic for leprosy.


MATERIAL AND METHODS
A retrospective study was conducted on the epidemiological and clinical evolution of 37 leprosy cases reported during 2018-2022 to the Palladio Health Information Center - Regional Health Information System, Iaşi, by the Regional Health Services in the Republic of Moldova.


RESULTS
A total number of 37 leprosy cases were reported to the Palladio Center, during 2018-2022, the average number being 30.55 cases/year. 25 (68%) cases had positive family history, five (14%) cases had positive personal history, as well, and seven (19%) cases registered family aggregation. In the case of 26 (70.3%) cases the diagnosis was established during a routine checkup, in 7 (18.9%) cases the diagnosis was established by chance and in four (11%) cases the diagnosis was established under clinical indicators. Multibacillary predominated over paucibacillary type (23 vs. 14). The most commonly observed forms were borderline leprosy (type 2: 17 cases - 45.9%) and tuberculoid leprosy (type 1: 16 cases - 43.2%).


CONCLUSIONS
The epidemiological situation of leprosy is constantly monitored, and the medical service continues to raise awareness

Influence of low dose bamboo shoot meal (Phyllostachys pubescens) supplementation on the lipid metabolism of adult male rats.
The present experimental study was envisaged to examine the role of low dose (40 g/kg body wt) bamboo shoot meal supplementation in the prevention of hyperlipidemia in adult rats. Thigh-muscular mass gain, body weight, and abdominal circumference were significantly lowered, and fat pad weight, body total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, triglycerides and blood sugar level, were significantly lowered. Bamboo shoot supplementation has resulted in significantly lower values of plasma cholesterol and triglycerides in comparison to the positive control group (P0.05). These findings suggest that adult rats can be used as a model to test efficacy as well as potential antihyperlipidemic effects of bamboo shoot meal as a functional food. This bamboo shoot meal could also be valuable in human nutrition and be an excellent source of dietary cholesterol-lowering agent. .

The sunflower, Helianthus annuus is a natural hybrid between the two species H. annuus and H. debilis. Despite the ecological and economic importance of this model system, the origin and extent of genomic differentiation between these two sunflower species remains mostly unknown. Here we apply a combined approach using both resequencing of whole genomes and genotyping of thousands of Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) to quantify the degree of genomic differentiation between the two parental species. We report the largest sequencing study to date of hybridizing plant species, which included 136 H. annuus genotypes and 61 H. debilis (including the two parental species). Using a Bayesian population structure analyses we show that the sunflower hybridogenetic cycle can best be described as a single subdivided gene pool, suggesting the occurrence of multiple backcross events since the divergence of the two species. We found no evidence of population structure among the two parental species and the hybrid populations, or for the isolation between parental genomes within interfertile populations. We were able to quantify individual-and population-specific allele inheritance in the hybrids via allelic imbalance, although this analysis was limited to the four parental haplotypes available. Analyses of genomic differentiation between the sunflower parental species revealed a surprisingly high level of sequence conservation between both species, with low frequencies of differentiated SNPs and low levels of differentiation at all hierarchical levels. However, a substantial number of regions of fixed differentiation, which are highly differentiated between parental genomes, were also observed. Although our results suggest that the hybridization between H. annuus L. and H. debilis L. is the result of a highly asymmetric hybridization event between large populations with similar population size, our findings indicate only a modest role of natural selection in shaping the genomic differentiation, despite the strong environmental differences between the niche of the two parental species. Interpreting Divergent Pathways to Intimate Partner Physical Aggression: The Role of Mood and Anger-Out in a Multiethnic Sample
The current study examined the relative importance of irritation and disgust as potential determinants of intimate partner physical aggression in men (n = 294) and women (n = 272) recruited from a multiethnic sample of low-income and minority young adults. All participants completed a self-report measure of intimate partner physical aggression and measures of anger-out, trait anger, irritability, and disgust. After accounting for the influences of anger-related variables and disgust, irritability was a significant predictor of intimate partner physical aggression for both genders. The results suggest that irritation may be a better discriminator of intimate partner physical aggression among heterogeneous groups than other anger-based variables. The study highlights the importance of interpreting mood characteristics in a developmental and ecological context. To test the antiplatelet action of thromboxane (TX) inhibition, we randomly selected four non‐splenectomized patients with disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and treated them for 6–40 days with the active metabolite of OKY‐046, a potent TX synthetase inhibitor, and assessed the platelet recovery. The patients' platelets were incubated with arachidonic acid and the generation of TXB2 was determined as a marker for TX production. Before treatment the platelet aggregability, assessed with a turbidity method, was abnormal in every patient. Three of the patients had TX levels between 1.2 and 3.6 pmol/108 platelets before treatment, indicating an impairment of TX metabolism in spite of normal TX, plasma levels. After start of treatment, the platelet TX activity increased in two patients because of both platelet activation and restoration of TX metabolism. The patients’ platelet aggregation response to arachidonic acid and collagen improved. After 40 days of treatment the platelet count had normalized in two of the patients. We conclude that treatment with OKY‐046 results in restoration of TX metabolism and platelet function in patients with DIC. PURPOSE
A phase I trial was conducted to test the toxicity and pharmacokinetics of two weekly courses of paclitaxel and gemcitabine in patients with advanced or refractory solid tumors.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
On day 1, 21 patients were scheduled to receive gemcitabine (900 mg/m2) followed 2 hours later by paclitaxel (100 mg/m2) in 24-hour catheter-free ambulatory treatment. In subsequent 16 courses, patients received paclitaxel (175 mg/m2) followed by gemcitabine (800 mg/m2). The dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) was defined as non-hematological severe toxicities. Pharmacokinetic studies were performed in 13 courses.


RESULTS
In 24 of 37 cycles (62.2%) DLT appeared. In the two-drug combination the DLTs were gemcitabine-related: mucositis grade 3 (n = 1), thrombocytopenia grade 3 (n = 2), neutropenia grade 4 (n = 2) and grade 3 hypernatremia (n = 1). All these cases appeared in courses with cumulative dose of gemcitabine > 3 g/m2 and cumulative dose of paclitaxel > 400 mg/m2. Pharmacokinetics showed no significant interaction either with regard to formation of Cremophor- or ethanol-solubilized species of paclitaxel.

Genetic characterization of the cysteine-type serine protease family and its regulators in Chinese flowering cabbage

Cysteine-type serine proteases (Cys-TPs) are important proteases that participate in various aspects of plant development and stress responses. We found 52 Cys-TPs genes in Chinese flowering cabbage, belonging to 11 subfamilies. Members of the SAG12 (SAG1-like protease) subfamily are the key regulators of senescence. Most of the Cys-TPs genes were strongly associated with age-and/or nutrition-induced leaf senescence, and the expression of some Cys-TPs genes was regulated by the interaction between ethylene (ETH) and jasmonic acid (JA). The expression levels of several Cys-TPs genes were associated with chlorophyll content in Chinese flowering cabbage. This study provides a significant foundation for the mining of Cys-TPs genes and their regulators in Chinese flowering cabbage.

# Introduction
Cysteine-type serine proteases (Cys-TPs) are widely distributed in plants and play an important role in various processes of plant growth and development. Serine proteases exist in plants, animals, and microorganisms, and their classification was defined in 1977 based on the amino-terminal amino acid residue of the enzyme. For example, bacterial serine proteases have cysteines in their N-terminus amide groups; plant serine proteases have aspartates, glutamate residues or serines; serine proteases in animals have glycine residues. Serine protease is a multi-functional protease that can be divided into 12 families by homologous alignment of amino acid structures. The proteases in the Cys-TPs family contain the catalytic histidine (H) residue in its active site and belong to the family of cystine-knot inhibitors.

The Influences of Aging on the Effects of Eye Movement on Cognitive Performance
Abstract Research into cognitive decline has indicated that even young and middle-aged people show a certain level of cognitive decline. Therefore, it is essential to understand the effects of the aging process on cognitive abilities to identify potential interventions for preventing a decline in related function. Research has shown that aging affects the oculomotor system by inducing neural degeneration and reducing visual perception function. Meanwhile, previous evidence has also shown that oculomotor functions, including eye movement, are closely related to cognitive function in both normal or pathological conditions, and the relationship between eye movement and cognition is bidirectional. Moreover, an increasing number of studies have found that aging affects some types of eye movement. However, to date, there has been little discussion of how the aging process affects cognitive function through these changes in eye movement. This review highlights the differences in each type of eye movement that are caused by aging and explores whether these changes affect cognitive performance, as well as the relationship between them. Based on this, we try to understand the effects of aging on the relationship between eye movement and cognition. Finally, based on recent studies, we discuss the potential of using eye movement to detect age-related cognitive decline and prevent age-related cognitive decline. OBJECTIVE
The purpose of this study was to characterize high-resolution CT (HRCT) findings in 35 patients with presigmoid petroclival meningioma and to document the location of tumors with respect to the middle fossa dural sinus and tentorial edge.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Thirty-five patients with HRCT studies and histologically proven presigmoid petroclival meningiomas were retrospectively reviewed. Patients were separated into two groups, 17 of which had petroclival meningiomas that involved the petrosal segment of the internal carotid artery (ICA-P), and a second group, with meningiomas that invaded or encased the middle fossa dural sinuses but did not extend deeply into the ICA-P. We reviewed the degree of tumoral bony erosion using the classification proposed by the American Joint Committee on Cancer, and we measured the distance to each patient's tumor from the middle fossa tentorial edge and middle fossa dural sinus using measurements referenced to the midline sphenoid sinus, to establish how these measurements correlated with the level of intracranial extension. The results were compared with the patient's age, sex, intracranial extension, and tumor size.


RESULTS
Tumors were predominantly solid (type III). There was significant overlap of the values for the various HRCT parameters in both groups. Age and tumor size were found to correlate with intracranial tumor extension.


CONCLUSION

Good! Inhaled Insulin Improves Glycemic Control in Patients with Poorly Controlled Diabetes Mellitus and Diabetes Insipidus
OBJECTIVE Insulin is often considered a therapy of last resort given the need for injection and the possibility of adverse effects. Insulin inhalation (INH) has been developed as an alternative to injected insulin. INH provides portal delivery of insulin to the lung and lymphoid tissue, and as a result, allows the insulin to be absorbed into the circulation while bypassing the portal liver system, avoiding hypoglycemia. MATERIALS AND METHODS We evaluated the efficacy and safety of two treatment regimens for patients experiencing poorly controlled diabetes with or without diabetes insipidus (DI). In patients with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus (DM), we evaluated 14 patients with type 1 DM (2 treated with continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion  or 12 treated with multiple daily injections ) and 2 patients with type 2 DM treated with subcutaneous injections. In patients with poorly controlled DM and DI, we evaluated 4 patients treated with INH only and 4 patients treated with INH+CSII or MDI. Results After one month of INH treatment, patients with poorly controlled DM experienced significant reduction in A1C levels and no new onset hypoglycemia. All treated patients experienced a significant reduction in insulin dose. INH in combination with CSII or MDI therapy resulted in significantly lower serum K levels and A1C compared with patients treated with CSII or MDI only. No adverse effects were reported. CONCLUSIONS Clinical experience of using INH for the treatment of poorly controlled DM or poorly controlled DM with DI suggests that INH provides glycemic control with improved A1C levels and no new onset hypoglycemia. INH also reduced the required insulin dose and improved renal tubular function. Methane emissions during the storage of manure and manure solids in deep-litter livestock systems.
Methane emissions from animal manure can be affected by storage conditions. The objective of this study was to assess methane emissions and N emission losses under field conditions from two feedlot lagoons and one pond used to store liquid and solid manure of cattle, swine, and chickens. The storage of liquid manure increased methane production and N emission losses compared with storage of solid manure. Pond storage of both types of manure had the greatest impact on increasing methane emissions compared with pits in feedlot lagoons, which in turn were greater than pits in commercial packing barns. Glycan structural variation affects human milk oligosaccharide (HMO)-associated bacteria and HMO consumption in human infants.
Human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs) form a diverse and complex maternal nutrient that provides signals to coordinate bacterial colonization and metabolism in infants. Structural variation of HMOs has been reported to contribute to interindividual differences in the infant microbiome. In this study, we measured the associations of HMO fucosylation and sialylation with early infant stool microbiota composition and metabolic profiles as well as the consumption of 13 HMOs. Fecal samples (n= 150) from infants age <3 months were analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) to measure fucosylation and sialylation ratios of 21 major HMOs. Gut microbiome profiling using shotgun metagenomic sequencing and metabolomics using untargeted liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) were performed for 80 randomly selected stool samples. Fecal calprotectin was also measured to detect intestinal inflammation. The study found that most infants (95%) were fecally colonized by one of the two major HMO non-consumers, Bifidobacteria and Veillonellaceae (Prevotella). Background: Tuberculin skin test (TST) is the standard screening method to detect latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI) among healthcare workers (HCWs). BACKGROUND
The diagnosis of epilepsy remains an open question for paediatricians, and the definition of a new and standardised method seems to be difficult, due to the lack of an objective method to investigate this diagnosis. The aim of this study is to investigate the validity of the use of a new, not standardised method, in children and adolescents attending the Epilepsy Clinic of the Children's Hospital of Messina, Italy, from 1998 to 2007 and then to verify the hypothesis of the influence of the parents' education of epilepsy on the quality of the information provided.


METHODS
The study group consists of 198 children and adolescents. For each patient, we registered the name of the parents, the number of siblings and the degree of school education received by the parents. The diagnostic certainty was evaluated through a retrospective study of the clinical history. The quality of the information provided was evaluated with the application of a questionnaire.


RESULTS AND CONCLUSIONS
The diagnostic uncertainty was higher among children with a poorer degree of school education of the parents and in cases of the presence of siblings. Better diagnostic certainty was achieved in those cases where the parents' education level was high, and a low number of siblings were present. Children whose parents have a higher level of education, in particular the mother, provided more information. The new method proved to be effective for evaluating the diagnostic certainty and the quality of the information provided by the parents, especially in the case of complex forms of epilepsy.  The Fos, Jun, Maf, and FoxC transcription factors are expressed in the developing neural fold and neural crest of Xenopus tropicalis
The vertebrate neural crest is an embryonic vertebrate structure that gives rise to many diverse tissues including cartilage, bone, melanocytes, and neurons and glia. We have investigated the transcription factors and signaling pathways that induce and regulate neural crest development in the frog Xenopus tropicalis. Here, we have investigated the expression of transcription factors of the Fos, Jun, and Maf families, two members of the CNC (CFR) family of transcription factors, and FoxC1 and FoxC2, a divergent member of the Fox family, in the developing neural crest and mid‐hindbrain region of Xenopus tropicalis. We show that (1) the Jun B gene is expressed in the mid‐hindbrain region at the midblastula stage, (2) c‐myc, c‐jun, junB mRNAs are expressed in the mid‐hindbrain and/or neural crest regions at the neurula stage, and (3) c‐myc and FosB are expressed in the neural crest and mid‐hindbrain at the neurula stage, at or near the time of neural crest induction. We also show that (4) Maf F and c‐Maf mRNAs are expressed in the hindbrain and neural crest at the neurula stage, and that (5) c‐Jun, FoxC1, and FoxC4 mRNAs are expressed in the neural crest at the neurula stage. These results show that the transcription factor network of the mid‐hindbrain and neural crest regions is organized differently from the network in the forebrain. BACKGROUND & AIMS
It is generally assumed that the esophagus is innervated only via the sympathetic nervous system. We report here the existence of a prominent, but underappreciated, parasympathetic innervation.


METHODS
Forty-nine rats and 1 dog underwent intracardial perfusion fixation with 2% glutaraldehyde after bilateral cervical vagotomy. After staining to highlight myelinated axons, the lengths and numbers of vagal axons infiltrating into the cervical esophagus were determined using point-counting and light microscopy.


RESULTS
Bilateral vagotomy was successful in all but 1 rat. Esophageal tissue from rats was collected from the level of the pharynx to 5.7 mm (median) below the distal esophagogastric junction. Overall, the esophagus was heavily innervated by vagal fibers. On average 15.7% (+/- 4.4) of the esophageal length was infiltrated by vagal axons and consisted mostly of unmyelinated axons (68.3%; +/- 13.9). Vagal axons innervated the entire length of the esophagus in 6 out of 49 rats, while in others they were seen in a patchy manner with the highest density in the gastric cardia.


CONCLUSIONS
This is the first report on a significant parasympathetic innervation of the distal esophagus. These fibers, mostly unmyelinated,

Insulin-free 3H-cAMP lipogenesis from catecholamine in fat pads was significantly decreased to 39% in rats fed a HFD compared with those fed a low-fat diet (p < 0.001). Furthermore, basal and epinephrine- and isoproterenol-induced release of free fatty acids from rat adipocytes was significantly decreased to 40% and 52% (p < 0.001), respectively, in fat cells from rats fed a HFD compared with their counterparts from rats fed the low-fat diet. Insulin inhibition of cAMP-stimulated lipolysis was significantly impaired in adipocytes from rats fed a HFD (p < 0.05). Great! Now, we're all on the same page and ready to move forward. Improving outcomes in complex renal cell carcinoma: a comparison of four treatment series
We collected and compared the outcomes of four treatment groups of patients with complex renal cell carcinoma in a retrospective study of 201 patients. We evaluated the effectiveness of four treatment groups, and evaluated four treatment series. All patients had a renal tumour with a diameter greater than 10cm or with vascular invasion or lymph node metastases. The groups included the treatment with radical nephrectomy (126 patients), patients who underwent a partial nephrectomy (28 patients), patients who were submitted to a nephron‐sparing surgery (22 patients), and patients who received percutaneous ablation (35 patients). A comparison of survival curves revealed no significant differences between different treatment types, and the overall five‐and 10‐year survival rates were similar in different series. The most significant prognostic factors were the renal function of the operated kidney and tumour size. Based on our retrospective data, we consider the treatment of the renal cell carcinoma complicated by a high tumour stage as a surgical problem, irrespective of the treatment type. An important issue to be discussed is the value of nephron‐sparing surgery in patients with complex renal cell carcinoma. Because of the risk of local recurrence and metastases, we consider partial nephrectomy justified only for the kidneys with tumours of low malignancy grade. Copyright © 2001 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd. The importance of early surgery in adults with acute complicated colonic diverticulitis Background and aimsThe optimal management of acute complicated colonic diverticulitis is controversial. We aimed to assess whether complications are prevented, by early surgery, in the presence of multiple intraoperative risk factors. Patients and methods All adult patients (n = 250) with acute complicated colonic diverticulitis between 1997 and 2011 were retrospectively collected. Patients were grouped according to the timing of surgery in two groups; early surgery (d 5, n = 26) or delayed surgery (d 6, n = 89) and the groups were compared. Results In comparison with the delayed surgery group, the early surgery group had significantly reduced in-hospital mortality (13%, n = 3 versus 60%, n = 15 patients, respectively; P = 0.001). In-hospital complications (46%, n = 12 versus 81%, n = 66; P = 0.001), anastomotic leakage (25%, n = 2 versus 46%, n = 40; P = 0.043), and the rate of faecal diversion (3%, n = 1 versus 39%, n = 35, respectively; P \ 0.001) were significantly reduced. Conclusions Patients with multiple intraoperative risk factors are at increased risk of complications and are at risk of being treated unnecessarily by a prolonged course of systemic antibiotics. The results suggest that early surgery is a safe treatment and is associated with a decreased need for a faecal diversion in this group of patients. # Introduction The incidence of colonic diverticulitis

The evolution of sex determination and dosage compensation under the regulatory control of a genital development modifier

Background:In many species, Y chromosome evolution seems to coincide with a transition to sex chromosome-specific dosage compensation of genes. This transition appears to require evolution of at least three sex-limiting gene systems: sex determination, sex-specific dosage compensation and sex-limited genital development. One model of sex determination proposes that an X-linked dosage saturation factor (Dsf) suppresses sexually dimorphic development such that genetically male embryos express female-typical development when Dsf is expressed at high levels. If the Dsf regulates the dosage of a sex-determination modifier gene (Xdm), however, then the expression of Xdm should be regulated by the Dsf. Results: Experiments indicate that the Dsx and dsx transcripts encode the Dsf; the Dsf binds to several transcripts; and the Dsf regulates genital development in both the fly and the wasp. Conclusions: These results show that dosage saturation may occur via the regulatory suppression of the expression of a sex-determination modifier. The discovery of the genetic cascade linking the expression of a sex-determination modifier to the Dsf, and the expression of an XX-linked modifier (Xdm) to genital development, indicate that dosage compensation appears unlikely to occur if Xdm does not regulate development. Conversely, expression of the Xdm may be required for dosage compensation. Consequently, the evolution of sex chromosome-specific dosage compensation requires a series of regulatory interactions involving an X-linked developmental modifier, a sex-determination modifier, and sex-determination factors.
Dosage compensation is a gene regulatory mechanism thought to be involved in the co-evolution of sex chromosomes   The evolution of sex chromosomes, Charlesworth  . The genes governing interrelated biological processes such as cell and organ size are likely shared among distantly related plant lineages. To obtain insight into conserved mechanisms for cell type specification and biomass allocation, we generated molecular linkage maps to identify quantitative trait loci (QTL) that modulate various traits in a genetic background of Arabidopsis thaliana. Using these linkage maps, we identified QTL with large effects on fourteen traits including plant height, cell size, cell number per stem cross section, primary stem weight, secondary stem weight, number of cotyledonary leaves, number of leaves after first flower, internode width, petiole length, root length, plant weight, days to flowering, number of fertile stamens, and stamen length in two wild accessions (HKyu and SA01) as well as the laboratory accession (Columbia-0). Among the fourteen QTL, the largest effects on seven traits were found on chromosome 3 (HKyu), six traits (HKyu and SA01) mapped to chromosome 2 and chromosome 5 (Columbia-0) had the largest effects on single traits, respectively. We also identified 18 QTL with small effects on above 12 traits in each genetic background. Our results revealed a small scale of overlap of QTL for the traits, indicating that distinct factors regulate the traits. Interestingly, QTL with large and small effects modulated various traits, suggesting that pleiotropic genes underlie the QTL that control the traits.

Only 10-50 microL urine, 10 microliter internal standard (IS), and 100 microL methanol are needed to prepare a sample for this assay, and the entire analysis requires less than 9 min. The flow rate is 1.27 mL/min with a mobile phase of 50% methanol in a deionized water, 25 mm H3PO4 gradient system. A fluorescent detection system is utilized, and the UV-absorbances at 0.28 and 350 nm, with excitation at 274 nm, were used for quantitation. Urine samples from human volunteers who ingested oltipraz showed a characteristic time-dependent concentration profile of oxidative metabolites. AIM
To describe the characteristics of patients attended at primary care centres, to identify those who have high blood pressure and the percentage of patients treated successfully based on the results of the ENCOURAGE study.


DESIGN
Descriptive study of data of the ENCOURAGE study.


PARTICIPANTS
6 960 patients over 60 years of age who attended primary care centres.


INTERVENTION
The ENCOURAGE study used a questionnaire, ambulatory blood pressure and blood pressure readings at the consultation to evaluate hypertension, as well as a follow-up study to identify those who achieved an optimal level of blood pressure.


MAIN MEASUREMENTS
Measures of blood pressure, age, sex, body mass index, risk factors and medication treatment to lower blood pressure.


RESULTS
52.9 % of the sample had high blood pressure. 3,310 (47.6%) of the 6,960 attended patients who were over 60 years were classified as having high blood pressure, 45.1 % had stage 1 hypertension, 25.8 % had stage 2 hypertension and 11.9 % had uncontrolled hypertension according to the criteria used in the study. Successful control, that is, lowering of the blood pressure reading to less than 140/90 mm Hg, was obtained in 68.3% of the hypertensive patients treated with two drugs and 70.1 % with the use of three drugs.


CONCLUSION
Hypertension is a high risk factor for cardiovascular diseases and is very prevalent in people over 60. We should not restrict ourselves to monitoring the blood pressure but we should treat these patients too.

 Synthesis of Novel Pyrimidines as Inhibitors of Lens Aggretive Factor Activator Protease Activity (LAP)
Activator proteases (APs) of the C1 family play a crucial role in angiogenesis and lens agglutination syndrome. APs can be classified into pro‐ and anti‐angiogenic proteases. Pro‐APs induce cell‐cell interaction and vessel growth, while anti‐APs impair cell adhesion and hence angiogenesis. Angiogenesis is a hallmark of cancer and inflammation. A broad spectrum of cancer therapeutics exists to block angiogenesis. This is achieved by inhibiting APs, for which synthetic peptides and protein inhibitors were designed. We tested 2450 thiourea derivatives against liver LAP in a fluorogenic assay. The compounds are based on the AP recognition consensus motif (HXGGHXDLK), with HXG being the binding site for the serine protease‐activating component (SPAC). To test whether the resulting SPAC competitor and potent LAP inhibitor could cross the blood vessel barrier, we determined the blood‐brain barrier (BBB) score of the compound, which was higher than 1, but lowers than most BBB permeable drugs. We observed promising dose‐response dependency at 10 and 25 μM as well. In summary, a set of novel compounds was synthesized and tested in vitro, and one compound shows promise for LAP inhibition with good brain penetration capacity. .

The aim of this study is to investigate the feasibility of a 5-day course of oral idelalisib to rapidly clear CMV DNA in patients with HIV infection and advanced or recurrent cancers.

CMV has been associated with increased risk of disease progression and mortality in non-HIV-associated cancers. CMV is common in patients with HIV infection and advanced solid tumors. Previous studies have shown that early removal of CMV DNA can result in a slower growth rate of tumors . In patients with solid tumors that are CMV-positive, oral valganciclovir to clear CMV DNA after surgery and before starting cancer treatment is feasible and may be associated with slowed tumor progression . We hypothesize a similar effect in patients with HIV infection who have advanced solid tumors and who receive oral idelalisib. Previous reports have shown that idelalisib is associated with a decrease in total lymphocyte count and the majority of patients are CMV seropositive, suggesting that patients with advanced HIV infection and solid tumors may tolerate idelalisib and clear CMV DNA simultaneously. The purpose of this study is to enroll patients with advanced HIV infection who have advanced solid tumors and to evaluate the feasibility and safety of a 5-day course of oral idelalisib to clear CMV DNA versus patients receiving valganciclovir. Eligible patients will have advanced or recurrent cancer and be seropositive for CMV infection, not known to be CMV-positive, and receiving valganciclovir. Eligibility criteria include adequate renal function, adequate hepatic function, and the absence of severe congestive heart failure, angina, or significant arrhythmias. Three patients achieved complete response with the combination therapy and four had partial response, for an overall response rate of 63%. Biogas potential is mainly affected by substrate and AD processes conditions, while nutrients recovery is related with type of technology. Substrate composition of an agro-industrial waste is a variable factor to take into account for biomethane assessment. As a common practice, storage time of food and/or vegetable wastes is performed, to reduce their fresh content, improve degradability index and to obtain a stable mixture with manure. In this context, it would be interesting to evaluate the effects of short storage before anaerobic digestion and of lime addition during the storage, a simple, common and inexpensive amendment for wastes and manure. For this purpose, a full-scale biogas process with storage and separated storage has been tested during a year, in a plant using food, vegetables and animal wastes. The results show an improved biogas yield by lime treatment, both in storage and in digesters, whereas the digester and storages without lime displayed an initial phase with slower rate, that improved in the following days. Results indicate that a 1 g kg −1 lime was enough to increase biogas production and to reduce pH, for 2-3 days, while stabilizing the process before lime addition. The nutrients recovery decreased after 5-6 months to 35 and 40%, for nitrogen and phosphorus digestate, respectively, with a slight increase in lime digesters. Lime addition was ineffective in recover nitrogen, phosphorus and calcium since the amendment only washed off the content from vegetable and animal wastes, being lime added after storage.

Background—Although myocardial perfusion scintigraphy is the gold standard to diagnose coronary artery disease, it has limitations regarding radiation exposure and the use of nuclear tracers. In this study, we evaluated the diagnostic potential of a novel method to analyze myocardial perfusion in patients referred for stress perfusion scintigraphy. Methods and Results—Ninety-three patients received technetium-99m-sestamibi for stress perfusion scintigraphy according to standard protocols with the additional use of a 12-lead electrocardiogram. Regardless of outcome, all patients received a 99mTc-sestamibi redistribution scan. Myocardial uptake in the perfusion images was expressed in counts per pixel (CPP). At the end of the redistribution scan, a second image was obtained to analyze the spatial distribution of remaining 99mTc-sestamibi. These analyses allowed us to calculate a quantitative measure of remaining activity per pixel (QPP). In patients with myocardial infarction, QPP was low in noninfarcted muscle and high in the infarcted area. In patients with no myocardial damage, QPP was uniformly low. Receiver operating characteristic curve analysis showed that QPP is a diagnostic marker for the presence of myocardial damage; however, the highest accuracies were achieved when using the CPP and QPP ratios comparing stress and redistribution images. Conclusions—Our results suggest that analysis of myocardial 99mTc-sestamibi distribution offers a potential new clinical tool to detect myocardial damage in patients referred for myocardial perfusion scintigraphy. The diagnostic value of these new parameters needs to be confirmed in larger patient studies. The purpose of this study was to evaluate the use of a high-definition stereotactic system (HDRS) for treatment of multiple brain metastases when a fiducial-based system is not optimal.

RESULTS
For 39 lesions, 1 planning image was acquired, and HDRS-radiosurgery was performed 1 to 9 times. For 18 lesions, 2 planning images were acquired, and HDRS-radiosurgery was performed 1 to 3 times. The mean localization error at the first and second time of HDRS radiosurgery was 0.28 and 0.43 cm, respectively. No significant difference was observed in the localization error between 2 planning images (P = 0.318).


CONCLUSIONS
HDRS radiosurgery is a feasible and safe alternative to a fixation marker- or frame-based system in the HDRS radiosurgery. The authors were not able to demonstrate a statistically significant difference in the accuracy of HDRS-radiosurgery between the 2 planning images. Percutaneous transhepatic dilatation of a sphincterotomy defect can be performed safely and effectively without laparotomy. Eighty six sphincterotomies in 70 patients were assessed and dilatation was performed up to a maximum of 23 mm. Dilatation of small to medium sized defects up to 10-12 mm in diameter was successful and uneventful while dilatation of much larger defects (> 12 mm) was less successful and was associated with an increased (10%) incidence of post-operative bleeding. A variety of causes for failure of dilatation, including large duct calculi and duct stenoses were encountered. In most centres, percutaneous transhepatic dilatation is best reserved for patients with failed or incomplete sphincterotomy or significant duct stricture after failed sphincterotomy. Molecular detection of HIV infection in dried stool specimens collected and preserved on filter paper
Recently, a PCR‐based method has been proposed for the detection of HIV nucleic acid in dried blood stains on filter paper for the use of genetic epidemiological studies on historical HIV infections. The method is based on the extraction of nucleic acids from staphylococcal colonies grown in medium agar plates spread with the dried blood stains. In this study, HIV detection was attempted in stool specimens from 111 HIV‐seropositive individuals, collected, and preserved on filter paper 6‐16 h after defecation. HIV nucleic acids were detected in 83 stool extracts (75.6%) and the PCR assay sensitivity was assessed by testing serial dilutions of PCR‐amplified target DNA. To evaluate the effects of storage periods of the stool filtrates at −20°C and −70°C on HIV detection, HIV amplification was carried out at weekly intervals during 3 months in 34 samples. A significant difference (P < 0.0001) in HIV detection results was observed: 86% (30/35) of DNA extracts obtained from storage of stool filtrates at −20°C showed HIV DNA; whereas 50% of samples (7/14) stored at −70°C tested positive. A direct relationship (P < 0.0001) was found between virus detection and the total number of leukocytes per ml of feces. A new method of measuring changes in vagal tone in humans is described. With this technique, it is possible to monitor the effect of autonomic drugs on vagal tone. It is of interest because the effect of autonomic drugs can be studied within the time frame of individual drug trials. This technique was compared with the widely used method of pharmacological blockade of the sympathetic nervous system. For this comparison 47 patients who were scheduled for coronary bypass surgery were divided into two groups. One group received intravenous propranolol and the other group received atropine by mouth before the study; each group also received the other drug during the study. In both groups, the heart rate increased after drug administration, but the response was greater in patients who received propranolol than in those who took atropine. This difference was statistically significant (P less than .001, paired t test). In each group, there was considerable variation in the increase in heart rate to propranolol and atropine. The variation could not be explained by such factors as age, sex, or time of day. The new technique was found to be reproducible, whereas the traditional method of using pharmacological blockade was not. The new method allows the effect of a drug on vagal tone to be studied in a time frame adequate for clinical trials. There is a high rate of relapse (35%) after chemotherapy in patients with advanced colorectal carcinoma, but there is only a small percentage of progression in clinical parameters. The relapse rate is highest in Dukes'B colorectal cancer and decreases with more advanced tumour stages. The relapse rate seems to be independent of the number of metastasised lymph nodes, type of anastomosis (end-to-end, side-to-end), presence of blood vessels, lymph vessels or nerves in the resection margins, as well as whether the tumour was graded G2 or G3; the only possible prognostic factor was Dukes' stage. No correlation between relapse rate and resected lymph node number, lymphadenectomy extension with a high number of resected lymph nodes, or surgical lymphatic clearance was found. A clear resection margin of less than 5 mm did not increase the risk of relapse; this is because no tumour cells were found in a distance of up to 10 cm from the tumour at the resection margin. PAP2 is a 145-kDa DNAand RNA-binding protein that exhibits sequence homology with the 74-kDa hsPAP and the 64-kDa yeast pbp1 gene products. We describe in this report a novel, highaffinity, nonsequence-specific, DNA-binding domain of PAP2 located in the N-terminal half of the protein. The 74-kDa fragment bound preferentially to AT-rich sequences that did not require a specific consensus motif. The consensus sequence, AATT(T/C), however, strongly inhibited binding, thereby supporting the notion that PAP2 is involved primarily in transcription. This conclusion was further strengthened by chromatin association studies in which we showed that PAP2 associated primarily with DNA that was complexed with nucleosomes and that it had no obvious preference for a specific chromatin fraction.PAP2 also appeared to bind preferentially to AT-rich segments of heterochromatin. Too cold,

and bought the shoes from the store.
When I told her that I had already
bought the new shoes a week before, she was shocked and disappointed.
I bought it because it was my daughter's birthday and
I wanted to buy something for her.
At that moment, I felt like a failure and disappointed that she didn't like
my decision.
So, the Goldilocks effect is when you compare or choose something beyond your
limit or range, and you end up realizing that you could have done a better job.
Goldilocks effect is how we usually end up making regrettable mistakes.
Goldilocks effect is when you realize that you could have done a better job than you did, or

Goldilocks effect is when you feel that you could have made a good decision
if you had waited.
Goldilocks effect is how to make an ordinary matter extraordinary.
When I was working in the ward, I had a patient with a cough, and I wanted to

I wanted to check his chest X-ray before giving

Just when I arrived at the radiology room, a nurse was preparing a patient for chest X-ray.
So, I wondered what would happen if I went to another hospital.

The aminopeptidase N (APN, EC 3.4.11.2, CD13) is a transmembrane metalloproteinase expressed on normal and malignant cells. In the tumor cell APN, several proteolytic activities toward exogenous peptides as well as on receptor and growth factors have been described. In addition the activity of APN toward oligopeptides is up-regulated and the enzyme becomes associated with the plasma membrane. Therefore, APN is a potential target for tumor specific therapy and the structure of the enzyme was explored to identify the sites responsible for the various functions of APN. Our strategy was to identify amino acid residues specifically involved in the catalytic activity of APN and others of importance for substrate binding, as illustrated by several recently published crystal structures. To study the functional role of certain residues or domains of APN, we were looking for inhibitors that can discriminate between normal and tumor tissue-expressed enzyme. A series of synthetic hexapeptides with C-terminal amide were identified. These peptides, with the common structure of a sequence of leucines or the sequence of a single leucine, inhibit the exopeptidase activity of APN while simultaneously stimulating the enzymatic hydrolysis of a synthetic APN substrate. These dual-acting peptides do not compete with the binding of leucine to the specific domain of APN but they specifically bind to the non catalytic subdomain involved leucinamides binding. The aim of this review is to summarize the general pathways of fat absorption, with special attention focused on the molecules that enable fatty acids to cross the apical membrane of enterocytes. These pathways can vary depending on the fatty acid chain, but include passive diffusion of short- and medium-chain fatty acids, facilitated diffusion of long-chain fatty acids and transport with specific transporters of long- and very-long-chain fatty acids. The review highlights the importance of microsomal triglycerides, which is composed of two triglycerides, an anionic micelle containing phospholipids, a bilayer of fatty acid chains and cholesterol. These factors are essential for packing lipids into small and medium chylomicrons that can be absorbed through simple diffusion. However, hydrolysis can take place in microsomal triglycerides, releasing glycerols and free fatty acids. In addition, these fatty acids can interact with microsomal triglycerides to produce new molecules for fatty-acid absorption that can be transported by the enterocyte. Absorbed fatty acids and the newly formed transport systems are important for the development and differentiation of enterocytes, which suggests the hypothesis that fat absorption plays an important role in these processes. .

The MICCAI Multi-modality Image registration Tasks and Data sets (MID) group has established an annual workshop dedicated to the registration of medical images. The goal of this workshop is to provide a forum for exchange of ideas and experience with image registration in medical imaging. The second edition was dedicated to the registration of multiple modalities, including multi-modality image registration. It was held May 20 -23, 2009, in Boston, MA, USA and was followed by a special session at the International Conference on Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention (MICCAI) 2009, held May 25-29 at St Annes School for Boys in London, UK. The workshop served as a platform for the 5th MICCAI Challenging Functional and Structural Adaptive Registration (CFSAR) Symposium that was held as a special session on May 25, 2009. This issue of the journal presents the papers and results of the workshop and the symposium. It also includes the winner of the challenge, with their published paper. In order to provide the readers with background information and context, some articles published in one of the previous issues of the journal have also been included.

## About the special issue and workshop
MICCAI strives to bring together the key innovations, results, and findings of the MICCAI community, thus serving two important functions. One function of the journal is to highlight and disseminate the research contributions and findings from the MICCAI community. A second function is to serve as a key publication venue for the MICCAI proceedings, including the main and challenging papers presented at the MICCAI scientific conferences.
A unique subset of the MICCAI community consists of the participants who attend the international workshop, which is a major part of the annual international MICCAI conferences. The workshop, under the umbrella and support of the MICCAI society, has attracted over 74 workshop co-chairs and 211 workshop speakers to present their cutting-edge research advances. Dramatic changes in human sperm function and sperm population structure upon cryopreservation: a clinical biopsychosocial perspective.
Despite a century of research, human sperm remains a biological enigma. Our inability to predict sperm function in vitro has stymied our clinical efforts to deliver human sperm that are effective in aiding in vitro fertilization. In this clinically focused review, we examined human sperm physiology from both a scientific and clinical perspective. Through a review of human and nonhuman biology, we hypothesized that when human ejaculates are cryopreserved, they can become physiologically and pathologically trapped in a state of 'cold' shock, resulting in significant dysregulation of sperm function and population structure. Cryopreservation was found to promote the expression of molecular 'cold shock' proteins by human sperm. As a clinical biologic consequence, cryopreservation increases human sperm's susceptibility to oxidative stress, and as a result, cryopreservation exacerbates sperm functional impairment. We examined a variety of sperm cellular organelles, including mitochondria, plasma membrane and epididymal protein, and their impact on cryopreservation-associated dysfunctions. Cryopreservation was also found to decrease seminal plasma components that could potentially protect sperm against the deteriorating effects of low temperature, and it may reduce sperm-ovum interaction. As we begin to better appreciate these pathophysiological phenomena, we can begin to consider additional and innovative options in improving sperm's efficiency in human reproduction. Abstract We developed a novel multiplex PCR by targeting four pathogenic bacteria, i.e., Listeria, Salmonella, Campylobacter and Shigella. Primer sets for the detection of four respective bacteria were designed based on the unique 16S rRNA gene sequences. The specificity of the primer set for Listeria was checked by blast analysis. The sensitivity of the multiplex PCR was determined by serial dilutions of extracted DNA of the cultured four bacteria. The detection limit was found to be as low as, 50 pg. The specificity of the PCR was tested by the DNA templates extracted from 300 other bacterial strains. The specificity results show only Listeria and Salmonella are detected. BACKGROUND
Reconstructive surgery of intrauterine adhesion (IUA) can reduce the incidence of intrauterine adhesions but has no effect on uterine atrophy and endometrium necrosis, which may be closely related to the inflammatory response of the uterus, especially to the expression of C/EBP homologous protein (CHOP) in the endometrial epithelial cells. In order to clarify the expression of CHOP during remodeling of endometrium and uterus after IUA.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Rat models of IUA were established and divided into three groups: control, model and treatment. At day 12, day 24 and day 35 after surgery, we evaluated the thickness of the endometrial wall, the height of the endometrium and the length of the endometrial gland. Western blot and RT-PCR were used to investigate the expression of CHOP protein and mRNA respectively.


RESULTS
There were significant differences in the thickness of the endometrial wall and the height of endometrium between the model and the control at day 12 and day 35. At all the time points, the expression of CHOP was significantly increased in IUA group compared to the control. Also at day 24 and day 35 the model group had higher expression levels of CHOP mRNA. However, in the treatment group the IUA-induced CHOP elevation was effectively blocked.


CONCLUSIONS
The expression of CHOP protein and mRNA elevated significantly in the model and treatment groups, which indicated that the inflammatory responses of the uterus might be suppressed by blocking CHOP expression. The most common complications were acute mucositis, with 154 (69.3 percent), and chronic rhinosinusitis with 51 (22.9 percent). The complications were significantly associated with primary tumor site, age, and gender. In the multivariate analysis, only age and gender were associated with complications. Inherited diseases that result from the X-linked, autosomal recessive, or autosomal dominant inheritance patterns of single-gene disorders have been an important focus of gene therapy research. In this report, we describe the first application of hematopoietic progenitor cells for gene therapy of the X-linked disorder, X-linked chronic granulomatous disease (X-CGD). A lentiviral preparation was designed containing the therapeutic gene for the X-CGD enzyme, X-linked γ-subunit, human gp91-phox, in the reverse orientation under the control of an internal ribosome entry site and the ubiquitous phosphoglycerate kinase-1 promoter. Using a γ-retroviral packaging vector, high titers in excess of 108 genomic copies/ml were obtained for a lentiviral preparation in 293FT cells. The preparation was then evaluated in primary, cord blood-derived CD34+ cells. The transduced CD34+ cells could be expanded in vitro, as evidenced by maintenance of the progenitor cell phenotype as well as transduced gene expression. Transduction and transgene expression were stable in long-term cultures up to 35 days after lentivirus exposure. The lentiviral vectors transduced the CD34+ cells with high efficiency (>70%), and transduction was enhanced by prior exposure to interleukin-3. These initial studies demonstrate the feasibility of using lentiviruses for clinical gene therapy of X-CGD. BACKGROUND
We aimed to investigate serum progesterone in women with primary epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC), and to determine its usefulness in the diagnosis of early ovarian cancer.


MATERIALS AND METHODS
Four-hundred-and-two women underwent laparotomy for ovarian masses of possible clinical concern; among them, 122 were pathologically diagnosed with EOC. All EOC samples were of invasive variety. Serum progesterone levels were examined. Correlations between serum progesterone levels and tumor stages and grades were determined.


RESULTS
Serum progesterone levels were significantly raised in advanced stages, grades, and in patients older than 45 years. A significant negative correlation was found between serum progesterone levels and tumor stages. There was a significant positive correlation between serum progesterone levels and tumor grades in patients with stage II disease.


CONCLUSION
Serum progesterone levels are raised in patients with early ovarian cancer, especially in women older than 45 years. They are significantly higher in those with advanced grades and stages. Therefore, we are of the opinion that evaluation of the tumor grade and stage along with serum progesterone levels may be helpful in the diagnosis and management of this deadly disease. The etiology of hepatocellular carcinoma, its molecular epidemiology and histologic diversity, clinical course, and management have much in common with many other human neoplasms. This paper, however, is a brief overview of liver tumor progression, rather than a comprehensive review; thus, important topics are left out, the reader being referred to reviews by others on many aspects of liver tumorigenesis. The emphasis is on clinical hepatocellular carcinoma, which shows a diverse histologic spectrum from low-grade through high-grade cords or trabeculae/pseudoacini to high-grade noninvasive and invasive cancer, although this pathologic progression is not the only pattern seen. The molecular alterations in many tumors follow an evolutionary model in which the accumulation of genetic events drives the process. While the early events can be explained by intrinsic derangements of the gene products by the mutated genes, the late events likely reflect clonal evolution. The tumor development in many cancers, however, is heterogeneous; tumor progression is the result of a continuous clonal evolution from one neoplastic cell to another, even, as for human prostatic cancers, within the prostatic acinar cell. The heterogeneous proliferation of cells in most cancers also increases the opportunity for mutations of genes regulating cell cycle regulators and signal transduction. Such heterogeneity makes it difficult to establish a specific model for tumorigenesis for each individual cancer. The molecular mechanisms by which tumors acquire their invasive, metastatic potentials also vary considerably among individual malignancies. In liver tumorigenesis, a unique molecular pathways are often activated. SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and pediatric

AIMS To measure the relationship between fear of hypoglycemia and the subsequent recovery from hypoglycemia in patients with insulin-treated diabetes. METHODS Patients with diabetes were recruited who regularly used insulin, but who were known not to be treated with oral sulfonylureas. The 18 patients included all women with type I diabetes and 11 male and four female patients, all with type II diabetes. Participants had to have either experienced at least one hypoglycemic episode per week in the 3 months before the start of the study or, otherwise, had been hypoglycemic frequently enough for participants to believe, from experience, that they were particularly prone to have hypoglycemia. They each completed a hypoglycemic fear questionnaire on the way into the examination room before taking part in the adrenaline and glycerol infusion clamp test for measurement of endogenous recovery from hypoglycemia. Participants who showed a reduced recovery on this test were invited back again 1 to 2 weeks later for measurement of their ability to recover from hypoglycemia using exogenous glucose infusion. RESULTS The participants showed a wide range of individual susceptibility to developing post-hypoglycemic cognitive dysfunction (range 0–59 min, n = 13), and their mean level of fear of hypoglycemia was 13.6 (median 8.5, n = 18). 2 -Deoxy-2 -fluoro-D-glucose (FDG) PET is an established imaging modality in oncology and research. Recently, we reported a method to accurately measure transport of FDG and other fluorinated glucose analogues into the brain. This study evaluates FDG transport into rat brain under basal conditions and in the presence of pharmacologic agents that block various glucose transport pathways. Rats were subjected to either pharmacological inhibition of the sodium-dependent component of glucose transport or infusion of 2-deoxy-D-glucose (2DG) as a blocker of facilitated glucose transport into the brain. FDG and 2 DG were determined in the blood and brain at multiple times up to 24 hr after infusion. The uptake of FDG within 1 min and the transport clearance were dependent on the presence of blood-borne sodium, which was blocked with amiloride. Infusion of 2-deoxy-D-glucose (2DG) reduced the influx of FDG by 72%. To verify this competition effect, the time course of 2DG transport into the brain was also evaluated under various external conditions. A linear relationship was observed between FDG transport and 2DG transport, suggesting that the two substrates share the same transport pathway. 2 DG transport was also compared in brain with other tissues, and a much higher influx was observed in the brain than in other tissues. In summary, FDG transport into the brain appears to be dependent on blood-borne sodium, with a lower apparent affinity than for glucose transport into the tissue. The effects of anticholinergic prophylaxis on the duration of mechanical ventilation and duration of hospitalization in critically ill elderly patients: a prospective randomized study.
Objective
The study explores whether the anticholinergic prophylaxis given in early period contributes to reducing the duration of mechanical ventilation and hospitalization in critically ill elderly patients.


Method
A prospective randomized study was conducted with 130 elderly patients (> 65 years) in the intensive care unit between March 1, 2018 and January 1, 2019. 65 participants received anticholinergic prophylaxis (A group) and 65 participants received no anticholinergic prophylaxis (R group).


Results
On the 3rd day, patients in groups (A, R) had no statistically significant difference in terms of sedation (p=0.446) and agitation (p=0.602). When the results of the 3rd and 7th days are compared, a statistically significant difference was found in terms of agitation in groups (A, R) (p=0.038, p=0.026). The need for re-intubation was not statistically significant between groups A and R during mechanical ventilation (p=0.343).


Conclusion
Although anticholinergic prophylaxis does not make a statistically significant difference in the need for re-intubation and mechanical ventilation duration, it significantly contributes to shorten the 3rd and 7th days agitation in critically ill elderly patients. Ecocriticism in the History of Landscape and Nature
The article seeks to reintroduce the method and conceptual framework of ecocriticism into the history of landscape and nature. It examines its history, development, and current issues, particularly as they refer to the analysis of literary and artistic representation. The ecocritical perspective suggests that nature in art and literature was and is influenced by the social and economical context, for example, the enclosure movement, urbanization, and industrialization/agricultural revolution. Ecocriticism can be used as an analytic method in the historical, cultural, environmental, or artistic context. It can also be integrated with historiography in general. Since the late 1970s, ecocriticism has been a popular method in the study of literature, art, philosophy, and other interpretive fields and social sciences, such as environmental science and human ecology. The article also discusses the current theoretical discourse on the term “ecocriticism,” which is a controversial subject in the field of environmental humanities. Background: This secondary analysis examined whether the association between physical activity and body mass index (BMI) is mediated by time spent in different screen-based sedentary behaviors (screen-SB) in a nationally representative sample of US elementary agedschool aged-children. Methods: Data came from the 2003-2006 cycles of the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES). A total of 393 US children (5-10.9 years old) were included. Physical activity was reported by the child's parent and screen-based sedentary behaviors were self-reported. BMI was regressed on weekday and weekend physical activity and weekday and weekend screen-SB, controlling for demographic variables, physical activity, and screen-based sedentary behaviors' interactions. Analyses were also stratified by gender and race-ethnicity. In order to examine the mediation effect of sedentary screen-based behaviors in the relationship between physical activity and BMI, the product-of-coefficients method was used.Results: For the total study sample, physical activity was negatively associated with child's BMI (b = − 0.06, p = 0. 0001) and positively associated with screen-based sedentary behaviors (b = 0.51, p = 0.0001). Enantioconvergent synthesis of chiral gamma-amino acid derivatives.
A general methodology for the enantioconvergent synthesis of chiral gamma-amino acid derivatives is described. Reaction of alpha,alpha-disubstituted amino acid methyl esters with a gamma-iminoester affords the corresponding 2-pyrrolidinone derivatives in a highly stereoselective process. Alternatively, addition of aqueous formaldehyde to the amino acid methyl ester derivatives in the presence of a basic catalyst provides enantiomerically enriched 3-hydroxy-4-pyrrolidinone derivatives. These transformations provide access to both the D- and L-enantiomers, and their corresponding proline derivatives.  Improving the accuracy of a biochemical diagnostic method of depression in people with neurodegenerative diseases and its use as a depression screening tool in neurodegenerative populations

Neurodegenerative diseases and depression have similar underlying pathology. Depression is a common comorbidity of neurodegenerative diseases and affects the quality of life of the patients. Many patients with dementia, like those with Alzheimer's disease, are unable to describe their physical and psychological problems; therefore, neuropsychiatric assessment tools are needed to identify depression in this population. We studied whether the blood level of soluble tumor necrosis factor receptors (sTNFRs) and liver-type fatty acid-binding protein (L-FABP) (the biochemical index of neurodegeneration) could help diagnose depression in patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD), Parkinson's disease (PD), and multiple system atrophy (MSA). We found that soluble tumor necrosis factor receptor type 1 (sTNFR1) and sTNFR2 levels were higher in the depressive group than in the nondepressive group. The ratio of sTNFR1 to sTNFR2 in the depressive group was lower than that in the nondepressive group. Further, liver-type fatty acid-binding protein content was higher among Parkinson's disease patients with depression than in those without depression. We could not diagnose patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) nor multiple system atrophy (MSA) depression (n=5 each) using this method; 18 of 20 Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients with depression (nondepressive AD: 12 patients) were tested and were diagnosed correctly, except for one AD patient and one multiple system atrophy (MSA) patient. We propose a new diagnostic method for depression in people with dementia disease using sTNFR1 and sTNFR2 levels, which will be useful for the identification of depression in neurodegenerative diseases.

As the number of human cellular proteins susceptible to post-translational ubiquitination continues to increase, interest in ubiquitin chemistry has intensified recently. One of the major goals in ubiquitin chemistry has been to discover inhibitors of this system to be used in studying the mechanisms of ubiquitination, as well as to test the potential of modulating ubiquitination as a therapeutic tool. To meet this goal, we have generated a high-throughput screening assay for E1-independent inhibitors of ubiquitination. By using the recently developed UbcH5 protein as E2 in the ubiquitination assay and the N-terminal 382 amino acids of ubiquitin (Ubi382) as the substrate, we have set-up a procedure capable of identifying either small molecules or larger polypeptides capable of inhibiting the formation of isopeptide or peptide bonds in the ubiquitination reaction. To screen the enzyme/substrate pair for inhibitors, the time of ubiquitination is measured in the presence of a control substrate, poly-ubiquitin, and an inhibitor, and the initial reaction rate is calculated. Since many proteins of the ubiquitination cascade are E1-independent, this assay is suitable to screen for non-E1 inhibitors. Consequently, this assay is very valuable to screen for ubiquitination inhibitors of known E1-independent enzymes

In 43.4% of the operated-on patients there was no loss of substance of the anterior cruciate ligament which has not occurred so rarely in this type of injury, as could be concluded from previous studies. There was a statistically significant correlation between the degree of severity of the injury in the torn ligament and the length of the postoperative rehabilitation period. However a correlation between the degree of severity of the injury in the torn ligament and prognosis of anterior cruciate ligamental insufficiency was not established. The incidence of renal calculi was studied in a population of 650 000 inhabitants in the Paris area. An apparent high incidence (6.31 cases per 10,000 per year) was found in the northern suburbs and a much lower rate (4.34 cases per 10,000 per year) in Paris. In 13 patients in whom surgery was performed, the calculi were characterized and classed by their chemical nature. The proportion of compounds rich in calcium was much higher in the Paris region. Our study indicates the existence of two different types of nephrolithiasis in the metropolitan area, of which one is characterized by the predominance in incidence in Paris and high chemical calcium content of the calculi, the other being observed mainly in the northern suburbs and characterized by a low calcium content. These differences in the incidence and chemical composition of the calculi in the eastern and western districts of the Paris area suggest that the geographic variation in calculogenesis in the Paris area is multifactorial rather than being related to a single factor as has been suggested in previous studies. The prevalence of a given type of nephrolithiasis in Paris could be related to the different types of drinking water (private or public) consumed by the inhabitants of the region. .

In this model, 40 g rats accelerated (12.5 m/second) in a modified rotatory acceleration device, undergo a severe rotatory acceleration brain injury. Using this model the neurological sequelae of diffuse axonal injury are reproduced in rats, a species which is well amenable to chronic neuropathological and long-term behavioral testing. Immediate post-injury management strategies, including cooling, rehydration, glucose, barbiturates, hypertonic sodium lactate, and phencyclidine treatment, appear to be devoid of beneficial neurological outcome. Results: We show that in contrast to naïve rat VSMCs, the NFAT5 expression level was significantly increased in differentiated human VSMCs and was induced by acute hypotonic medium switch. In response to hypotonic conditions, NFAT5 was associated with the promoter region of a variety of different genes in human VSMCs. By integrating transcriptome profiles, we identified distinct clusters of gene expression patterns in response to hypotonic medium, which included the topmost upregulated mRNA of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress gene UPR-associated SEL-10-interacting protein (UPR11), N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor 2b (GRIN2B), and NFAT5 co-factor NFAT interacting zinc finger protein 2 (NZF2) associated with pro-inflammatory cytokine (IL6) expression. Additionally, over-expression and depletion of NFAT5 in human VSMCs confirmed its function as pro-inflammatory regulator.Conclusions: By integrating transcriptome profiles, we identified distinct clusters of gene expression patterns in human VSMCs in response to hypotonic environment. Bifurcation-induced synchronization of two coupled chaotic oscillators.
We propose a scheme to synchronize two coupled chaotic oscillators using bifurcation-induced effects. The scheme is based on the observation that the two identical dynamical systems under study can be mapped onto each other by a bifurcation parameter of a control parameter. When the value of this parameter passes a suitable bifurcation, the two chaotic systems synchronize with each other. We find that a phase synchronization emerges naturally as a result of bifurcation, independent of the control parameter. The system parameters for which the synchronization takes place are estimated with the help of the amplitude equation method. We apply the method to the two identical Lorenz or two identical Chen systems and we observe that these systems synchronize when the control parameters or bifurcation parameters change in a suitable manner by crossing (or switching on/off) some critical values. The dentate gyrus (DG) is a region of the hippocampus critical for new information processing. It has anatomical connectivity with other structures, particularly the perforant pathway from the entorhinal cortex. With aging and the onset of dementia, the perforant pathway begins to deteriorate significantly, compromising the function of the DG. There is both human and rodent data indicating that the ability of the DG to process and store information declines with aging. In addition, rodent research has provided molecular evidence of DG deficits associated with aging and with progression towards the clinical diagnostic of Alzheimer disease (AD). Therapeutically, stimulating the DG may offer promise as a disease-modifying treatment in the AD brain. Abstract Many older adults with multiple chronic conditions have difficulty managing their care. This study compared the GPCT to usual primary care, the continuity clinic model (CC), for older adults with multiple chronic conditions. Adults (age 60+) over 1 year participated in either an interdisciplinary team clinic: primary care provider (GPCT) and a nurse health coach and/or standard care: primary care provider (CC). Participants with complete data for one-year pre- and post-enrollment were included (75% GPCT, 91% CC). Multivariable linear and multivariable logistic regression analyses modeled the relationship of treatment assignment on self-efficacy for managing chronic conditions, change in number of chronic conditions, number of emergency department visits, and number of hospitalizations. Patients assigned to the GPCT clinic had significantly higher pretreatment self-efficacy compared to CC (7.4 vs. 6.9, p=.01). Bactobolin Exerts an Anticancer Activity by Inhibiting LXR/FASN and PI(3)K/AKT Pathways in Hepatocellular Carcinoma
Fatty acid synthesis is an important factor that drives proliferation of tumor cells. Fatty acid synthase (FASN) is an important enzyme in the process of fatty acid synthesis and is highly expressed in clinical tumors. FASN expression is highly consistent with tumor characteristics, and its overexpression is associated with cancer progression and prognosis. Therefore, FASN is expected to become a target for cancer treatment. Bactobolin is a novel indole alkaloid isolated from the plant Claviceps purpurea, which has various pharmacological activities, including antibacterial, antioxidant, and anticancer activities. Whether bactobolin can inhibit liver cancer by inhibiting fatty acid synthesis is still unknown. Therefore, the effect of bactobolin against hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) needs to be further explored. In this study, we found that bactobolin inhibited proliferation and induced apoptosis and autophagy of Hep3B and MHCC97H cells in vitro by inhibiting the expression of fatty acid synthase. Overexpression of FASN significantly reversed the inhibitory effect of bactobolin on the proliferation of Hep3B cells and the increased expression of apoptosis proteins. In addition, to further explore the effect of bactobolin on HCC progression, we constructed a Hep3B xenograft nude mice model. We found that bactobolin inhibited tumor growth and liver mass index. The expression of fatty acid synthase and PI(3)K/AKT pathway-related proteins also decreased in the bactobolin group, in comparison with the control group

- Inclusion criteria in the research plan. Molecular Dynamics Simulations of Ion Transport and Electrostatic Response in Graphene-Based Supercapacitors.
Graphene-based supercapacitors have attracted considerable interest due to their fast energy storage at high power densities. The high internal surface area of graphene combined with its highly conductive electronic and ionic transport pathways make it an ideal electrode material for supercapacitors. This review article discusses recent development in our understanding of ion-transport characteristics and electric response of graphene-based supercapacitive electrode (GSEE) materials based on molecular dynamics simulations. The results show that electrostatic and electromechanical properties of graphene sheets are very sensitive to their structure, especially the curvature. This effect is particularly strong in the case of charged supercapacitors with nanoscale thickness. We found that in the presence of charges, the curvature can drastically change the nature of electrostatic interaction between graphene sheets, resulting in attractive or repulsive interelectrode interaction even in the same polarization direction. Molecular dynamics simulations of ion transport through functionalized GSEE materials demonstrate that functionalization of GSEE surfaces with polar groups may increase the mobility of the ions. The increased mobility is explained by the reduction of the electrostatic potential near the electrode-electrolyte interface. Moreover, the presence of functional groups can change the local electric potential difference across the electrode due to asymmetric placement of charged species on the opposite surfaces of the sheets, thus lowering the total energy of the system. The phytochelatin synthase (PCS) gene family encodes PCS enzymes, the key enzyme involved in plant metal tolerance. Identification and functional characterization of PCS genes are of great importance in understanding the molecular adaptability of plants to metal stress. In this study, fourteen GmPCS genes were identified in soybean based on genome-wide analysis. We found all of the GmPCS genes contain three domains with a conserved Cys-Cys-Gly-Cys motif. Phylogenetic analysis indicated that the GmPCS family could be clustered into three main groups and their expression patterns differed significantly. The expression of GmPCS1, GmPCS2 and GmPCS4 was significantly induced by Cd stressed treatment. Transgenic Arabidopsis overexpressing GmPCS1, GmPCS2 and GmPCS4 accumulated higher levels of Cd compared with wild type plants. Furthermore, the transgenic plants accumulated higher concentrations of PC2 than wild type plants under Cd stress. These results suggested that GmPCS1, GmPCS2 and GmPCS4 were involved in the detoxification of heavy metals, especially Cd, in plants. GmPCS4 had higher transcript level compared with GmPCS2 and GmPCS1 when treated with excess Cd for different time, indicating GmPCS4 may play a major role in soybean adapting to Cd-stressed environment. These findings are valuable for developing new cultivars for soybean breeding and for studying the molecular function and mechanism of PCS proteins in plants.

Objectives: This research was conducted to clarify the relationship between dentists' recommendations on periodical dental visits with oral cancer, the relationship between the dentist's recommendations on periodical dental visits and the incidence of oral cancer, and factors contributing to the awareness of periodic dental visits.Method: Literature was reviewed on the relation between dentists' advice and incidence of oral cancer. Articles that reported prospective observational or randomized controlled studies examining the relationship between dentists' recommendations and oral cancer were included.Results: Three prospective observational studies and one randomized controlled trial were included in the present review. There was a statistically significant relationship between dentists' advice and oral cancer incidence. The participants' awareness of periodic visits to the dentist was significantly associated with the recommendations of their dentist regarding visiting the dentist. The participants' attitude toward periodical dental visits was the only significant factor of their knowledge about oral cancer. A number of studies were conducted on assessing the effect of periodical dental visits based on a case-control method.Conclusion: Evidence from prospective studies suggests that adhering to dentists' guidance significantly reduces the risk of oral cancer. As participants with higher knowledge of oral cancer are more likely to have a better attitude towards dental visits, providing effective health education to patients will help enhance their attitude toward visiting a dentist at regular intervals. The study was designed to assess the relationship between hepatic inflammatory cell infiltration detected by immunostaining for CK in chronic alcoholic liver disease (CALD) and serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST), total protein (TP), albumin, alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and aldehyde dehydrogenase‐2 (ALDH2).
